Two quasigroups Q(·) and Q(◦) are isotopic if there are bijections α, β, γ of the set Q onto itself such that x ◦ y = γ(αx · βy) for all x, y ∈ Q. It is well-known that all quasigroups that are isotopic to groups form a variety G. Let V be a variety of quasigroups. Characterize the class of groups isotopic to quasigroups in G ∩ V. For which identities characterizing V is every group isotopic to a quasigroup in G ∩ V? Under what conditions on V does any group isotopic to a quasigroup in G ∩ V consist of a single element?
V. D. Belousov, A. A. Gvaramiya
answer: Every part is answered (A. A. Gvaramiya, Dep. no. 6704-V84, VINITI, Moscow, 1984 (Russian)).

problem_text:
A finite group is called quasi-nilpotent (Γ-quasi-nilpotent) if any two of its (maximal) subgroups A and B satisfy one of the conditions 1) A ⩽ B, 2) B ⩽ A, 3) N_A(A ∩ B) ̸= A ∩ B ̸= N_B(A ∩ B). Do the classes of quasi-nilpotent and Γ-quasi-nilpotent groups coincide?
Ya. G. Berkovich, M. I. Kravchuk
answer: No. The group G = ⟨x, y, z, t | x4 = y4 = z2 = t3 = 1, [x, y] = z, [x, z] = [y, z] = 1, x^t = y, y^t = x−1y−1⟩ is Γ-quasi-nilpotent, but not quasi-nilpotent. Since G/Φ(G) ∼= A4, the intersection of any two maximal subgroups A and B of G equals Φ(G), whence N_A(A ∩ B) ̸= A ∩ B ̸= N_B(A ∩ B); thus G is Γ-quasi-nilpotent. On the other hand, if A1 = ⟨zx2, zy2, t⟩ and B1 = ⟨z, t⟩, then N_{A1}(A1 ∩ B1) = A1 ∩ B1 = ⟨t⟩; hence G is not quasi-nilpotent. (V. D. Mazurov, 1973.)

problem_text:
(S. Chase). Suppose that an abelian group A can be written as the union of pure subgroups Aα, α ∈ Ω, where Ω is the first non-denumerable ordinal, Aα is a free abelian group of denumerable rank, and, if β < α, then Aβ is a direct summand of Aα. Does it follow that A is a free abelian group?
Yu. A. Bogan
answer: Not always (P. A. Griffith, Pacific J. Math., 29 (1969), 279–284).

problem_text:
Find the cardinality of the set of all polyverbal operations acting on the class of all groups.
O. N. Golovin
answer: It has the cardinality of the continuum (A. Yu. Olshanskii, Math. USSR–Izv., 4 (1970), 381–389).

problem_text:
(A. I. Mal’cev). Do there exist regular associative operations having the heredity property with respect to transition from the factors to their subgroups?
O. N. Golovin
answer: Yes, there do (S. V. Ivanov, Trans. Moscow Math. Soc., 1993, 217–249).

problem_text:
Prove an analogue of the Remak–Shmidt theorem for decompositions of a group into nilpotent products.
O. N. Golovin
answer: Such an analogue is proved (V. V. Limanski˘ı, Trudy Moskov. Mat. Obshch., 39 (1979), 135–155 (Russian)).

problem_text:
(Well-known problem). Let G be a periodic group in which every π-element commutes with every π′-element. Does G decompose into the direct product of a maximal π-subgroup and a maximal π′-subgroup?
S. G. Ivanov
answer: Not always.

problem_text:
Does there exist a torsion-free group such that the factor group by some term of its upper central series is nontrivial periodic, with a bound on the orders of the elements?
G. A. Karas¨ev
answer: Yes, such groups do exist (S. I. Adian, Proc. Steklov Inst. Math., 112 (1971), 61–69).

problem_text:
A group G is called conjugacy separable if any two of its elements are conjugate in G if and only if their images are conjugate in every finite homomorphic image of G. Is G conjugacy separable in the following cases:
a) G is a polycyclic group,
b) G is a free soluble group,
c) G is a group of (all) integral matrices,
d) G is a finitely generated group of matrices,
e) G is a finitely generated metabelian group?
M. I. Kargapolov
answer:
a) Yes (V. N. Remeslennikov, Algebra and Logic, 8 (1969), 404–411); E. Formanek, J. Algebra, 42 (1976), 1–10).
b) Yes (V. N. Remeslennikov, V. G. Sokolov, Algebra and Logic, 9 (1970), 342–349).
c), d) Not always (V. P. Platonov, G. V. Matveev, Dokl. Akad. Nauk BSSR, 14 (1970), 777–779 (Russian); V. N. Remeslennikov, V. G. Sokolov, Algebra and Logic, 9 (1970), 342–349; V. N. Remeslennikov, Siberian Math. J., 12 (1971), 783–792).
e) Not always.

problem_text:
Is it true that the wreath product A ≀ B of two groups that are conjugacy separable is itself conjugacy separable if and only if either A is abelian or B is finite?
M. I. Kargapolov
answer: No (V. N. Remeslennikov, Siberian Math. J., 12 (1971), 783–792).

problem_text:
Compute the ranks of the factors of the lower central series of a free soluble group.
M. I. Kargapolov
answer: They were computed (V. G. Sokolov, Algebra and Logic, 8 (1969), 212–215; Yu. M. Gorchakov, G. P. Egorychev, Soviet Math. Dokl., 13 (1972), 565–568).

problem_text: Are finitely generated subgroups of a free soluble group finitely separable? M. I. Kargapolov
answer: Not always (S. A. Agalakov, Algebra and Logic, 22 (1983), 261–268).

problem_text: Is it true that the wreath products A≀B and A1 ≀B1 are elementarily equivalent if and only if A, B are elementarily equivalent to A1, B1, respectively? M. I. Kargapolov
answer: No, but if the word “elementarily” is replaced by the word “universally,” then it is true (E. I. Timoshenko, Algebra and Logic, 7, no. 4 (1968), 273–276).

problem_text: Do the classes of Baer and Fitting groups coincide? Sh. S. Kemkhadze

b) An abstract group-theoretical property Σ is called radical (in our sense) if, in any group G, the join Σ(G) of all normal Σ-subgroups is a Σ-subgroup. Is the property N^0 (see Archive, 1.38) radical? Sh. S. Kemkhadze
answer:
No.
The group SLn(Z) for sufficiently large n ⩾ 3 contains a non-abelian finite simple group and therefore is not an N^0-group.
On the other hand, as shown in (M. I. Kargapolov, Yu. I. Merzlyakov, in: Itogi Nauki. Algebra. Topologiya. Geometriya, 1966, VINITI, Moscow, 1968, 57–90 (Russian)), it is the product of its congruence-subgroups mod 2 and mod 3, which have central systems and hence are N^0-groups (see Archive, 1.38). (Yu. I. Merzlyakov, 1973.)

problem_text: a) A subgroup H of a group G is called quasisubinvariant if there is a normal system of G passing through H. Let K be a class of groups that is closed with respect to taking homomorphic images. A group G is called an R0(K)-group if each of its non-trivial homomorphic images has a non-trivial quasisubinvariant K-subgroup. Do R0(K) and RN coincide when K is the class of all abelian groups? Sh. S. Kemkhadze
answer: No, they do not (J. S. Wilson, Arch. Math., 25 (1974), 574–577).

problem_text: b) Do there exist groups that are linearly orderable in countably many ways? A. I. Kokorin
answer: Yes, there do (R. N. Buttsworth, Bull. Austral. Math. Soc., 4 (1971), 97–104).

problem_text:
Does the class of finite groups in which every proper abelian subgroup is contained in a proper normal subgroup coincide with the class of finite groups in which every proper abelian subgroup is contained in a proper normal subgroup of prime index?
P. G. Kontorovich, V. T. Nagrebetski˘ı
answer: No. Let B be a finite group such that B = [B, B] ̸= 1 and let r be the rank of B. Put A = ⊕_{p||B|} (Z/pZ)^{r+1} and G = A ≀ B. We define a homomorphism φ : G → A by setting (bf)φ = ∑_{x∈B} f(x), where b ∈ B and f ∈ F = Fun(B, A). Suppose that f^b = f for b ∈ B and f ∈ F. It is clear that fφ ∈ nA, where n = |b|. In particular, C_F(b)φ ⩽ pA ⩽ O_{p′}(A) if p | n. Every proper abelian subgroup H of G is contained in a proper normal subgroup. Indeed, we may assume that H ̸⩽ F. We fix an element bf ∈ H, where f ∈ F, b ∈ B, b ̸= 1. Let p be a prime dividing |b|. For any h ∈ H ∩ F we have bfh = hbf = bhbf = bfh^b, whence h = h^b. Hence (H ∩ F)φ ⩽ C_F(b)φ ⩽ O_{p′}(A). If T is the full preimage of O_{p′}(A) in G, then G/T ∼= (Z/pZ)^{r+1} and therefore H/H ∩ T is an elementary abelian p-group. The rank of it is ⩽ r, since H/H ∩ T embeds into B and H ∩ F ⩽ H ∩ T. Thus, HT is a proper normal subgroup containing H. On the other hand, F is a proper abelian subgroup that is not contained in any proper normal subgroup of prime index, since G/F ∼= B = [B, B]. (G. M. Bergman, I. M. Isaacs, Letter of June, 17, 1974.)

problem_text:
Does there exist a finite group in which a Sylow p-subgroup is covered by other Sylow p-subgroups?
P. G. Kontorovich, A. L. Starostin
answer: Yes, there does, for any prime p (V. D. Mazurov, Ural Gos. Univ. Mat. Zap., 7, no. 3 (1969/70), 129–132 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Can every group admitting an ordering with only finitely many convex sub-groups be represented by matrices over a field?
V. M. Kopytov
answer: No, not every. For example, the group G = ⟨a_n, b_n (n ∈ Z), c, d | [a_n, b_n] = c, a_n^d = a_{n+1}, b_n^d = b_{n+1}, [a_n, a_m] = [b_n, b_m] = [a_n, c] = [b_n, c] = 1 (n, m ∈ Z)⟩ is soluble and orderable with finitely many convex subgroups, but it is not residually finite and hence is not linear over a field. (V. A. Churkin, 1969.)

problem_text:
Is a direct summand of a direct sum of finitely generated modules over a Noether-rian ring again a direct sum of finitely generated modules?
V. I. Kuz’minov
answer: Not always (P. A. Linnell, Bull. London Math. Soc., 14 (1982), 124–126).

problem_text:
An inverse spectrum ξ of abelian groups is said to be acyclic if lim←(p) ξ = 0 for p > 0. Here lim←(p) denotes the right derived functor of the projective limit functor. Let ξ be an acyclic spectrum of finitely generated groups. Is the spectrum L ξα also acyclic, where each spectrum ξα coincides with ξ?
V. I. Kuz’minov
answer: The answer depends on the axioms of Set Theory (A. A. Khusainov, Siberian Math. J., 37, no. 2 (1996), 405–413).

problem_text:
(de Groot). Is the group of all continuous integer-valued functions on a compact space free abelian?
V. I. Kuz’minov
answer: Yes, it is. By (G. Nöbeling, Invent. Math., 6 (1968) 41–55) the additive group of all bounded integer-valued functions on an arbitrary set is free. Hence the group of all continuous integer-valued functions on the Chech compactification of an arbitrary discrete space is also free. For any compact space X there exists a continuous mapping of the Chech compactification Y of a discrete space onto X. This induces an embedding of the group of continuous integer-valued functions on X into the free group of continuous integer-valued functions on Y. (V. I. Kuz’minov, 1969.)

problem_text:
Describe the finite simple groups whose Sylow p-subgroups are cyclic for all odd p.
V. D. Mazurov
answer: This was done (M. Aschbacher, J. Algebra, 54 (1978), 50–152).

problem_text:
(Old problem). The class of rings embeddable in associative division rings is universally axiomatizable. Is it finitely axiomatizable?
A. I. Mal’cev
answer: No (P. M. Cohn, Bull. London Math. Soc., 6 (1974), 147–148).

problem_text:
Does there exist a non-finitely-axiomatizable variety of
a) (H. Neumann) groups?
b) of associative rings (the Specht problem)?
c) Lie rings?
A. I. Mal’cev
answer:
a) Yes, there does (S. I. Adian, Math. USSR–Izv., 4 (1970), 721–739; A. Yu. Ol’shanskiĭ, Math. USSR–Izv., 4 (1970), 381–389).
b) Yes, there does (A. Ya. Belov, Fundam. Prikl. Mat., 5, no. 1 (1999), 47–66 (Russian), Sb. Math., 191, no. 3–4 (2000), 329–340; A. V. Grishin, Fundam. Prikl. Mat., 5, no. 1 (1999), 101–118 (Russian); V. V. Shchigolev, Fundam. Prikl. Mat., 5, no. 1 (1999), 307–312 (Russian)). But every variety of associative algebras over a field of characteristic 0 has a finite basis of identities (A. R. Kemer, Algebra and Logic, 26, no. 5 (1987), 362–397).
c) Yes, there does (M. R. Vaughan-Lee, Quart. J. Math., 21 (1970), 297–308).

problem_text:
The I-theory (Q-theory) of a class K of universal algebras is the totality of all identities (quasi-identities) that are true on all the algebras in K. Does there exist a finitely axiomatizable variety of
a) groups,
b) semigroups,
c) (1) rings
(2) of associative rings
(i) whose I-theory is non-decidable?
(ii) whose Q-theory is non-decidable?
(3) of Lie rings
(ii) whose Q-theory is non-decidable?
whose I-theory (Q-theory) is non-decidable?
A. I. Mal’cev
answer:
a) Yes (Yu. G. Kleiman, Trans. Moscow Math. Soc., 1983, no. 2, 63–110).
b) Yes (V. L. Murskiĭ, Math. Notes, 3 (1968), 423–427).
c) (1) Yes (V. Yu. Popov, Math. Notes, 67 (2000), 495–504). (2i) No, it does not (A. Ya. Belov, Izv. Math. 74, no. 1 (2010), 1–126).
(2ii) and (3ii): Yes, it exists (A. I. Budkin, Izv. Altai Univ., 65, no. 1 (2010), 15–17 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Is the variety generated by
a) a finite associative ring;
b) a finite Lie ring;
c) a finite quasigroup
finitely axiomatizable?
d) What is the cardinality n of the smallest semigroup generating a non-finitely-
axiomatizable variety?
A. I. Mal’cev
answer:
a) Yes (I. V. L’vov, Algebra and Logic, 12 (1973), 156–167; R. L. Kruse, J. Algebra,
26 (1973), 298–318).
b) Yes (Yu. A. Bakhturin, A. Yu. Olshanskii, Math. USSR–Sb., 25 (1975), 507–523).
c) Not always (M. R. Vaughan-Lee, Algebra Universalis, 9 (1979), 269–280).
d) It is proved that n = 6 (P. Perkins, J. Algebra, 11 (1969), 298–314; A. N. Trakht-
man, Semigroup Forum, 27 (1983), 387–389).

problem_text:
A group G is called an FN-group if the groups γiG/γi+1G are free abelian and
T∞
i=1 γiG = 1, where γi+1G = [γiG, G]. A variety of groups M is called a Σ-variety
(where Σ is an abstract property) if the M-free groups have the property Σ.
a) Which properties Σ are preserved under multiplication and intersection of vari-
eties? Is the FN property preserved under these operations?
b) Are all varieties obtained by multiplication and intersection from the nilpotent
varieties N1, N2, . . . (where N1 is the variety of abelian groups) FN-varieties?
A. I. Mal’cev
answer:
a) The property FN is preserved by multiplication of varieties (A. L. Shmel’kin, Trans.
Moscow Math. Soc., 29 (1973), 239–252). The property FN is not preserved by the
intersection of varieties. The following example is due to L. G. Kov´acs. Let U and
V be the varieties of all nilpotent groups of class at most 4 satisfying the identities
[x, y, y, x] ≡1 and [[x, y], [z, t]] ≡1, respectively. Then U and V are FN-varieties
because 1) both of them are nilpotent of class 4 and contain all nilpotent groups of
class ⩽3, and 2) relatively free groups in U and V are torsion-free (well-known for V
and follows for U from (P. Fitzpatrick, L. G. Kov´acs, J. Austral. Math. Soc. Ser. A,
35, no. 1 (1983), 59–73)). On the other hand, U∩V is not an FN-variety because the
relatively free group in U ∩V of rank 3 is not torsion-free. Indeed, every torsion-free
group in U ∩V is of class ⩽3 (follows from the paper by Fitzpatrick and Kov´acs
cited above), and there is a 3-generated (exponent 2)-by-(exponent 2) group of class
precisely 4 in U ∩V. (A. N. Krasil’nikov, Letter of July, 17, 1998.)
b) Yes (Yu. M. Gorchakov, Algebra i Logika, 6, no. 3 (1967), 25–30 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Let A and B be subvarieties of a variety of groups M; then (AB) ∩M is
called the M-product of A by B, where AB is the usual product. Does there exist
a non-abelian variety M with an infinite lattice of subvarieties and commutative M-
multiplication?
A. I. Mal’cev
answer:
Yes, there does; for example, M = ApAp, where Ap is the variety of all abelian groups
of prime exponent p (Yu. M. Gorchakov, Talk of June 21, 1967, Krasnoyarsk).

problem_text:
(P. Hall). Prove or refute the following conjectures:
a) If a word v takes only finitely many values in a group G, then the verbal subgroup vG is finite.
c) If G satisfies the maximum condition and vG is finite, then v∗G has finite index in G.
Yu. I. Merzlyakov

Find conditions under which a finitely-generated matrix group is almost residually a finite p-group for some prime p.
Yu. I. Merzlyakov
answer: A finitely generated matrix group over a field of characteristic zero has a subgroup of finite index which is residually a finite p-group for almost all primes p (M. I. Kargapolov, Algebra i Logika, 6, no. 5 (1967), 17–20 (Russian); Yu. I. Merzlyakov, Soviet Math. Dokl., 8 (1967), 1538–1541; V. P. Platonov, Dokl. Akad. Nauk Belarus. SSR, 12, no. 6 (1968), 492–494 (Russian)). A finitely generated matrix group over a field of characteristic p > 0 has a subgroup of finite index which is residually a finite p-group (V. P. Platonov, Dokl. Akad. Nauk Belarus. SSR, 12, no. 6 (1968), 492–494 (Russian); A. I. Tokarenko, Proc. Riga Algebr. Sem., Latv. Univ., Riga, 1969, 280–281 (Russian)). See also some generalizations in (V. N. Remeslennikov, Algebra i Logika, 7, no. 4 (1968), 106–113 (Russian); B. A. F. Wehrfritz, Proc. London Math. Soc., 20, no. 1 (1970), 101–122).

problem_text:
In which abelian groups is the lattice of all fully invariant subgroups a chain?
A. P. Mishina
answer: Such groups were characterized (M.-P. Brameret, Séminaire P. Dubreil, M.-L. Dubreil-Jacotin, L. Lesieur, et C. Pisot, 16 (1962/63), no. 13, Paris, 1967).

problem_text:
(A. Selberg). Let G be a connected semisimple linear Lie group whose corresponding symmetric space has rank greater than 1, and let Γ be an irreducible discrete subgroup of G such that G/Γ has finite volume. Does it follow that Γ is an arithmetic subgroup?
V. P. Platonov
answer: Yes, it does (G. A. Margulis, Functional Anal. Appl., 8 (1974), 258–259).

problem_text:
(A. Selberg). Let Γ be an irreducible discrete subgroup of a connected Lie group G such that the factor space G/Γ is non-compact but has finite volume in the Haar measure. Prove that Γ contains a non-trivial unipotent element.
V. P. Platonov
answer: This is proved (D. A. Kazhdan, G. A. Margulis, Math. USSR–Sb., 4 (1968), 147–152).

problem_text:
(A. Borel, R. Steinberg). Let G be a semisimple algebraic group and RG the set of classes of conjugate unipotent elements of G. Is RG finite?
V. P. Platonov
answer: Yes, it is (G. Lusztig, Invent. Math., 34 (1976), 201–213).

problem_text:
(F. Bruhat, N. Iwahori, M. Matsumoto). Let G be a semisimple algebraic group over a locally compact, totally disconnected field. Do the maximal compact subgroups of G fall into finitely many conjugacy classes? If so, estimate this number.
V. P. Platonov
answer: Yes, they do, and a formula for this number is found (F. Bruhat, J. Tits, Publ. Math. IHES, 41 (1972), 5–251).

problem_text:
Can SL(n, k) have maximal subgroups that are not closed in the Zariski topology?
V. P. Platonov
answer: Yes, it can if k is either Q or an algebraically closed field of characteristic zero (N. S. Romanovski˘ı, Algebra i Logika, 6, no. 4 (1967), 75–82; 7, no. 3 (1968), 123 (Russian)).

problem_text:
b) Does SLn(Z), n ⩾ 2, have maximal subgroups of infinite index?
V. P. Platonov
answer: Yes, it does (G. A. Margulis, G. A. Soifer, Soviet Math. Dokl., 18 (1977), 847–851).

problem_text:
Let G be a vector space and Γ a group of automorphisms of G. Γ is called locally finitely stable if, for any finitely generated subgroup ∆ of Γ, G has a finite series stable relative to ∆. If the characteristic of the field is zero and Γ is locally finitely stable, then Γ is locally nilpotent and torsion-free. Is it true that every locally nilpotent torsion-free group can be realized in this way?
B. I. Plotkin
answer: No (L. A. Simonyan, Siberian Math. J., 12 (1971), 602–606).

problem_text:
Let Γ be any nilpotent group of class n − 1. Does Γ always admit a faithful representation as a group of automorphisms of an abelian group with a series of length n stable relative to Γ?
B. I. Plotkin
answer: Not always (E. Rips, Israel J. Math., 12 (1972), 342–346).

problem_text:
Let Γ be a Noetherian group of automorphisms of a vector space G such that every element of Γ is unipotent. Is Γ necessarily a stable group of automorphisms?
B. I. Plotkin
answer: Not if the field has non-zero characteristic (A. Yu. Olshanskii, The geometry of defining relations in groups, Kluwer, Dordrecht, 1991). This is true for fields of characteristic zero if the indices of unipotence are uniformly bounded (B. I. Plotkin, S. M. Vovsi, Varieties of group representations, Zinatne, Riga, 1983 (Russian)).

problem_text:
If G is a finite-dimensional vector space over a field and Γ is a group of automorphisms of G in which every element is stable, then the whole of Γ is stable (E. Kolchin). Is Kolchin’s theorem true for spaces over skew fields?
B. I. Plotkin
answer: Yes, it is, if the characteristic of the skew field is zero or sufficiently large compared to the dimension of the space (H. Y. Mochizuki, Canad. Math. Bull., 21 (1978), 249–250).

problem_text:
Let G be a group of automorphisms of a vector space over a field of characteristic zero, and suppose that all elements of G are unipotent, with uniformly bounded unipotency indices. Must such a group be locally finitely stable?
B. I. Plotkin
answer: Yes, it must, which follows from (H. Heineken, Arch. Math. (Basel), 13 (1962), 29–37). Moreover, such a group is even finitely stable, as follows from (E. I. Zel’manov, Math. USSR-Sb., 66, no. 1 (1990), 159–168).

problem_text:
Does the set of nil-elements of a finite-dimensional linear group coincide with its locally nilpotent radical?
B. I. Plotkin
answer: Not always. The non-nilpotent 3-generator nilgroup of E. S. Golod constructed by an algebra over Q is residually torsion-free nilpotent; hence it is orderable and therefore it is embeddable into GLn over some skew field by Mal’cev’s theorem (V. A. Roman’kov, 1978).

problem_text:
Does the adjoint group of a radical ring (in the sense of Jacobson) have a central series?
B. I. Plotkin
answer: Not always (O. M. Neroslavski˘ı, Vesci Akad. Navuk BSSR, Ser. Fiz.-Mat. Navuk, 1973, No. 2, 5–10 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Is an R-group determined by its subgroup lattice? Is every lattice isomorphism of R-groups induced by a group isomorphism?
L. E. Sadovski˘ı
answer: Not always, in both cases (A. Yu. Olshanskii, C. R. Acad. Bulgare Sci., 32, no. 9 (1979), 1165–1166).

problem_text:
Let a group G be the product of two subgroups A and B, each of which is nilpotent and satisfies the minimum condition. Prove or refute the following:
a) G is soluble; b) the divisible parts of A and B commute elementwise.
N. F. Sesekin
answer: Both parts are proved (N. S. Chernikov, Soviet Math. Dokl., 21 (1980), 701–703).

problem_text:
a) Let a group G be the product of two subgroups A and B, each of which is locally cyclic and torsion-free. Prove that either A or B has a non-trivial subgroup that is normal in G.
b) Characterize the groups that can be factorized in this way.
N. F. Sesekin
answer:
a) This was proved (D. I. Zaitsev, Algebra and Logic, 19 (1980), 94–106).
b) They were characterized (Ya. P. Sysak, Algebra and Logic, 25 (1986), 425–433).

problem_text:
Does there exist a finitely generated right-orderable group which coincides with its derived subgroup and, therefore, does not have the property RN?
D. M. Smirnov
answer: Yes, there does (G. M. Bergman, Pacific J. Math., 147, no. 2 (1991), 243–248).

problem_text:
(G. Baumslag). Suppose that F is a finitely generated free group, N its normal subgroup and V a fully invariant subgroup of N. Is F/V necessarily Hopfian if F/N is Hopfian?
D. M. Smirnov
answer: No, not necessarily (S. V. Ivanov, A. M. Storozhev, Geom. Dedicata, 114 (2005), 209–228).

problem_text:
(Well-known problem). Does there exist an infinite group all of whose proper subgroups have prime order?
A. I. Starostin
answer: Yes, there does (A. Yu. Olshanskii, Algebra and Logic, 21 (1982), 369–418).

problem_text:
Let G be a periodic group containing an infinite family of finite subgroups whose intersection contains non-trivial elements. Does G contain a non-trivial element with infinite centralizer?
S. P. Strunkov
answer: Not always (K. I. Lossov, Dep. no. 5528-V88, VINITI, Moscow, 1988 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Let Γ be the holomorph of an abelian group A. Find conditions for A to be maximal among the locally nilpotent subgroups of Γ.
D. A. Suprunenko
answer: These are found (A. V. Yagzhev, Mat. Zametki, 46, no. 6 (1989), 118 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Let A and B be abelian groups. Find conditions under which every extension of A by B is nilpotent.
D. A. Suprunenko
answer: These are found (A. V. Yagzhev, Math. Notes, 43 (1988), 244–245).

problem_text:
Do there exist divisible (simple) groups with maximal subgroups?
M. S. Tsalenko
answer: Yes, there do (V. G. Sokolov, Algebra Logic, 7 (1968), 122–126).

problem_text:
Suppose that a periodic group G is the product of two locally finite subgroups. Is then G locally finite?
V. P. Shunkov
answer: Not always (V. I. Sushchanski˘ı, Math. USSR–Sb., 67, no. 2 (1990), 535–553).

problem_text:
Is every Hall π-subgroup of an arbitrary group a maximal π-subgroup?
M. I. `Eidinov
answer: Not always (R. Baer, J. Reine Angew. Math., 239/240 (1969), 109–144).

problem_text:
Classify the faithful irreducible (infinite-dimensional) representations of the nilpotent group defined by generators a, b, c and relations [a, b] = c, ac = ca, bc = cb. (A condition for a representation to be monomial is given in (A. E. Zalesski˘ı, Math. Notes, 9 (1971), 117–123).)
S. D. Berman, A. E. Zalesski˘ı
answer: Classification of these representations up to equivalence does not seem to be feasible. D. Segal (Math. Proc. Cambridge Phil. Soc., 81 (1977), 201–208) proved that there exist primitive irreducible representations of this group (that is, representations that are not induced from a representation of any proper subgroup). There are results concerning classification of primitive ideals of the groups algebra of this group (over various fields). For instance, Zalesskii (ibid.) showed that every primitive ideal is maximal.

problem_text:
(Well-known problems). a) Is there an algorithm that decides, for any set of group words f1, . . . , fm (in a fixed set of variables x1, x2, . . .) and a separate word f, whether f = 1 is a consequence of f1 = 1, . . . , fm = 1?
b) Given words f1, . . . , fm, is there an algorithm that decides, for any word f, whether f = 1 is a consequence of f1 = 1, . . . , fm = 1?
L. A. Bokut’
answer: No, in both cases (Yu. G. Kleiman, Soviet Math. Dokl., 20 (1979), 115–119).

problem_text:
Describe the insoluble finite groups in which every soluble subgroup is either 2-closed, 2′-closed, or isomorphic to S4.
V. A. Vedernikov
answer: This follows from (D. Gorenstein, J. H. Walter, Illinois J. Math., 6 (1962) 553–593; V. D. Mazurov, Soviet Math. Dokl., 7 (1966), 681–682; V. D. Mazurov, V. M. Sitnikov, S. A. Syskin, Algebra and Logic, 9 (1970), 187–204).

problem_text:
An automorphism σ of a group G is called algebraic if, for any g ∈G, the minimal σ-invariant subgroup of G containing g is finitely generated. An automorphism σ of G is called an e-automorphism if, for any σ-invariant subgroups A and B, where A is a proper subgroup of B, A \ B contains an element x such that [x, σ] ∈B . Is every e-automorphism algebraic?
V. G. Vilyatser
answer: Yes, it is (A. V. Yagzhev, Algebra and Logic, 28 (1989), 83–85).

problem_text:
Let G be the free product of free groups A and B, and V the verbal subgroup of G corresponding to the equation x^4 = 1. Is it true that, if a ∈ A \ V and b ∈ B \ V, then (ab)^2 ∉ V ?
V. G. Vilyatser
answer: No, it is not. If A and B are free groups with bases a1, a2 and b1, b2, respectively, then, for example, the commutators a = [[a1, a2, a2], [a1, a2]] and b = [[b1, b2, b2], [b1, b2]] do not belong to V, but (ab)^2 ∈ V. Indeed, it follows from (C. R. B. Wright, Pacif. J. Math., 11, no. 1 (1961), 387–394) that a^2 ∈ V, b^2 ∈ V, and [a, b] ∈ V. (V. A. Roman’kov, Talk at the seminar Algebra and Logic, March, 17, 1970.)

problem_text:
Does there exist an infinite periodic group with a finite maximal subgroup?
Yu. M. Gorchakov
answer: Yes, there does (S. I. Adian, Proc. Steklov Inst. Math., 112 (1971), 61–69).

problem_text:
Need the number of finite non-abelian simple groups contained in a proper variety of groups be finite?
Yu. M. Gorchakov
answer: Yes, mod CFSG; see, for example, (G. A. Jones, J. Austral. Math. Soc., 17 (1974), 162–173).

problem_text:
An element g of a group G is said to be generalized periodic if there exist x1, . . . , xn ∈ G such that x−1_1 g x1 · · · x−1_n g xn = 1. Does there exist a finitely generated torsion-free group all of whose elements are generalized periodic?
Yu. M. Gorchakov
answer: Yes, there does (A. P. Goryushkin, Siberian Math. J., 14 (1973), 146–148). Another example is G = ⟨a, b | (b^2)^a = b^−2, (a^2)^b = a^−2⟩. Then N = ⟨a^2, b^2, (ab)^2⟩ is an abelian normal subgroup of G and G/N is non-cyclic of order 4. If a^2l b^2m (ab)^2n = 1, then after conjugating by a we get a^2l b^−2m (ab)^−2n = 1, whence a^4l = 1. In view of the obvious homomorphism G → Z(Aut Z) that maps a to the number 1 ∈ Z we have l = 0. Similarly, m = n = 0. Hence N is free abelian of rank 3. The squares of elements outside of N are non-trivial; for example, (a a^2l b^2m (ab)^2n)^2 = a^2 a^−1(a^2l b^2m (ab)^2n) a a^2l b^2m (ab)^2n = a^(4l+2) ≠ 1. Hence G is torsion-free. Since the square of any element x ∈ G belongs to N, we have x^2 (x^2)^a (x^2)^b (x^2)^(ab) = 1. (V. A. Churkin, 1973.)

problem_text:
Is the elementary theory of subgroup lattices of finite abelian groups decidable?
Yu. L. Ershov, A. I. Kokorin
answer: No (G. T. Kozlov, Algebra and Logic, 9 (1970), 104–107).

problem_text:
Let G be a finite group of n × n matrices over a skew field T of characteristic zero. Prove that G has a soluble normal subgroup H whose index in G is not greater than some number f(n) not depending on G or T. This problem is related to the representation theory of finite groups (the Schur index).
A. E. Zalesski˘ı
answer: This is proved mod CFSG (B. Hartley, M. A. Shahabi Shojaei, Math. Proc. Cambridge Phil. Soc., 92 (1982), 55–64).

problem_text:
3.15. A group G is said to be U-embeddable in a class K of groups if, for any finite submodel M ⊂ G, there is a group A ∈ K such that M is isomorphic to some submodel of A. Are the following groups U-embeddable in the class of finite groups:
a) every group with one defining relation?
b) every group defined by one relation in the variety of soluble groups of a given derived length?
M. I. Kargapolov
answer:
No, in both cases (A. I. Budkin, V. A. Gorbunov, Algebra and Logic, 14 (1975), 73–84). Another example. The group G =

⟨a, b | (b2)a = b3⟩

is non-Hopfian as proved in (G. Baumslag, D. Solitar, Bull. Amer. Math. Soc., 68, no. 3 (1962), 199–201) and therefore is not metabelian. We choose elements a, b, x1, x2, x3, x4 ∈ G such that w = [[x1, x2], [x3, x4]] ̸= 1, add to them 1, their inverses, and all the initial segments of the word w in the alphabet {xi}, and all the initial segments of the word a−1b2ab−3 and of each of the words xi in the alphabet of {a, b}. Let M be the resulting model. If M was embeddable into a finite group G0, then G0 would have to be metacyclic, and also would have to have elements satisfying [[x1, x2], [x3, x4]] ̸= 1, which is impossible. Hence G is not U-embeddable into finite groups. Since the group G/G(k) is also non-Hopfian for a suitable k (ibid.), it is not U-embeddable into finite groups for similar reasons. (Yu. I. Merzlyakov, 1969.)

problem_text:
3.17. a) Is a non-abelian group with a unique linear ordering necessarily simple?
b) Is a non-commutative orderable group simple if it has no non-trivial normal relatively convex subgroups?
A. I. Kokorin
answer: Not always, in both cases (V. V. Bludov, Algebra and Logic, 13 (1974), 343–360).

problem_text:
3.18. (B. H. Neumann). A group U is called universal for a class K of groups if U contains an isomorphic image of every member of K. Does there exist a countable group that is universal for the class of countable orderable groups?
A. I. Kokorin
answer: No (M. I. Kargapolov, Algebra and Logic, 9 (1970), 257–261; D. B. Smith, Pacific J. Math., 35 (1970), 499–502).

problem_text:
3.19. (A. I. Mal’cev). For an arbitrary linearly ordered group G, does there exist a linearly ordered abelian group with the same order-type as G?
A. I. Kokorin
answer: No (W. C. Holland, A. H. Mekler, S. Shelah, Order, 1 (1985), 383–397).

problem_text:
3.21. Let K be the class of one-based models of signature σ, ϑ a property that makes sense for models in K, and K0 the class of two-based models whose first base is a set M taken from K and whose second base consists of all submodels of M with property ϑ and whose signature consists of the symbols in σ together with ∈ and ⊆ in the usual set-theoretic sense. The elementary theory of K0 is called the element-ϑ-submodel theory of K. Are either of the following theories decidable:
a) the element-pure-subgroup theory of abelian groups?
b) the element-pure-subgroup theory of abelian torsion-free groups?
c) the element-ϑ-subgroup theory of abelian groups, when the set of ϑ-subgroups is linearly ordered by inclusion?
A. I. Kokorin
answer: No, in all cases (for a), c): G. T. Kozlov, Algebra and Logic, 9 (1970), 104–107, Algebra, no. 1, Irkutsk Univ., 1972, 21–23 (Russian); for b): É. I. Fridman, Algebra, no. 1, Irkutsk Univ., 1972, 97–100 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Let ξ = {Gα, πα
β | α, β ∈ I} be a projective system (over a directed set I) of finitely generated free abelian groups. If all the projections πα
β are epimorphisms and all the Gα are non-zero, does it follow that lim
←− ξ ≠ 0? Equivalently, suppose every finite set of elements of an abelian group A is contained in a pure finitely-generated free subgroup of A. Then does it follow that A has a direct summand isomorphic to the infinite cyclic group?
V. I. Kuz’minov
answer: Under the assumption of the continuum hypothesis, not always (E. A. Palyutin, Siberian Math. J., 19 (1978), 1415–1417). Another example, not using the continuum hypothesis, is given by the abelian group A = Zℵ1/N where N is the subgroup consisting of elements having countable support. Every countable subgroup of A is free abelian, which means that each finite subset of A is contained in a pure finitely generated free abelian subgroup. But A has no direct summand isomorphic to Z. Both properties can be verified using the standard ZFC axioms of set theory. (S. Corson, Letter of 26 August 2024).

problem_text:
(F. Gross). Is it true that finite groups of exponent pαqβ have nilpotent length ⩽ α + β?
V. D. Mazurov
answer: No, not always (E. I. Khukhro, Algebra and Logic, 17 (1978), 473–482).

problem_text:
(J. G. Thompson). Is every finite simple group with a nilpotent maximal sub-group isomorphic to some PSL2(q)?
V. D. Mazurov
answer: Yes, it is (B. Baumann, J. Algebra, 38 (1976), 119–135).

problem_text:
If G is a finite 2-group with cyclic centre and every abelian normal subgroup 2-generated, then is every abelian subgroup of G 3-generated?
V. D. Mazurov
answer: Not always (Ya. G. Berkovich, Algebra and Logic, 9 (1970), 75).

problem_text:
Under what conditions can a wreath product of matrix groups over a field be represented by matrices over a field?
Yu. I. Merzlyakov
answer: Conditions have been found (Yu. E. Vapne, Soviet Math. Dokl., 11 (1970), 1396–1399).

problem_text:
A torsion-free abelian group is called factor-decomposable if, in all its factor groups, the periodic part is a direct summand. Characterize these groups.
A. P. Mishina
answer: This is done (L. Bican, Commentat. Math. Univ. Carolinae, 19 (1978), 653–672).

problem_text:
Find necessary and sufficient conditions under which every pure subgroup of a completely decomposable torsion-free abelian group is itself completely decomposable.
A. P. Mishina
answer: These have been found (L. Bican, Czech. Math. J., 24 (1974), 176–191; A. A. Krav-chenko, Vestnik Moskov. Univ. Ser. 1 Mat. Mekh., 1980, no. 3, p. 104 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Are two groups necessarily isomorphic if each of them can be defined by a single relation and is a homomorphic image of the other one?
D. I. Moldavanski˘ı
answer: No, not necessarily (A. V. Borshchev, D. I. Moldavanski˘ı, Math. Notes, 79, no. 1 (2006), 31–40).

problem_text: (K. Ross). Suppose that a group G admits two topologies σ and τ yielding locally compact topological groups Gσ and Gτ. If the sets of closed subgroups in Gσ and Gτ are the same, does it follow that Gσ and Gτ are topologically isomorphic? Yu. N. Mukhin
answer: Not always (A. I. Moskalenko, Ukrain. Math. J., 30 (1978), 199–201).

problem_text: Suppose that every finitely generated subgroup of a locally compact group G is pronilpotent. Then is it true that every maximal closed subgroup of G contains the derived subgroup G′? Yu. N. Mukhin
answer: Yes, it is (I. V. Protasov, Soviet Math. Dokl., 19 (1978), 1208–1210).

problem_text: Describe the finite groups with a self-centralizing subgroup of prime order. V. T. Nagrebetski˘ı
answer: They are described. Self-centralizing subgroups of prime order are CC-subgroups. Finite groups with a CC-subgroup were fully classified in (Z. Arad, W. Herfort, Commun. in Algebra, 32 (2004), 2087–2098).

problem_text: (I. R. Shafarevich). Let SL2(Z)ˆand SL2(Z)−denote the completions of SL2(Z) determined by all subgroups of finite index and all congruence subgroups, respectively, and let ψ : SL2(Z)ˆ → SL2(Z)− be the natural homomorphism. Is Ker ψ a free profinite group? V. P. Platonov
answer: Yes, it is (O. V. Mel’nikov, Soviet Math. Dokl., 17 (1976), 867–870).

problem_text: Is every compact periodic group locally finite? V. P. Platonov
answer: Yes, it is (E. I. Zel’manov, Israel J. Math., 77 (1992), 83–95).

problem_text: (Kneser–Tits conjecture). Let G be a simply connected k-defined simple algebraic group, and Ek(G) the subgroup generated by unipotent k-elements. If Ek(G) ̸= 1, then Gk = Ek(G). The proof is known for k-decomposable groups (C. Chevalley) and for local fields (V. P. Platonov). V. P. Platonov
answer: The conjecture was refuted (V. P. Platonov, Math. USSR–Izv., 10, no. 2 (1976), 211–243).

problem_text: Let G be a group of order pα · m, where p is a prime, p and m are coprime, and let k be an algebraically closed field of characteristic p. Is it true that if the indecomposable projective module corresponding to the 1-representation of G has k-dimension pα, then G has a Hall p′-subgroup? The converse is trivially true. A. I. Saksonov
answer: No, not always: see Example 4.5 in (W. Willems, Math. Z., 171 (1980), 163–174).

problem_text: Is it true that every finite group with a group of automorphisms Φ which acts regularly on the set of conjugacy classes of G (that is, leaves only the identity class fixed) is soluble? The answer is known to be affirmative in the case where Φ is a cyclic group generated by a regular automorphism. A. I. Saksonov
answer: No, not always (Y. Fine, J. Group Theory, 22, no. 6 (2019), 1077–1087).

problem_text: Can the quasivariety generated by the free group of rank 2 be defined by a system of quasi-identities in finitely many variables? D. M. Smirnov
answer: No (A. I. Budkin, Algebra and Logic, 15 (1976), 25–33).

problem_text:
Let L(N4) denote the lattice of subvarieties of the variety N4 of nilpotent groups of class at most 4. Is L(N4) distributive?
D. M. Smirnov
answer: No (Yu. A. Belov, Algebra and Logic, 9 (1970), 371–374).

problem_text:
Is a 2-group with the minimum condition for abelian subgroups locally finite?
S. P. Strunkov
answer: Yes, it is (V. P. Shunkov, Algebra and Logic, 9 (1970), 291–297).

problem_text:
Let G be a compact 0-dimensional topological group all of whose Sylow p-subgroups are direct products of cyclic groups of order p. Then is every normal subgroup of G complementable?
V. S. Charin
answer: Yes, it is (M. I. Kabenyuk, Siberian Math. J., 13 (1972), 654–657).

problem_text:
Let H be an insoluble minimal normal subgroup of a finite group G, and suppose that H has cyclic Sylow p-subgroups for every prime p dividing |G : H|. Prove that H has at least one complement in G.
L. A. Shemetkov
answer: This was proved (S. A. Syskin, Siberian Math. J., 12 (1971), 342–344; L. A. Shemetkov, Soviet Math. Dokl., 11 (1970), 1436–1438).

problem_text:
Let σ be an automorphism of prime order p of a finite group G, which has a Hall π-subgroup with cyclic Sylow subgroups. Suppose that p ∈ π. Does the centralizer CG(σ) have at least one Hall π-subgroup?
L. A. Shemetkov
answer: Yes, it does, mod CFSG (V. D. Mazurov, Algebra and Logic, 31, no. 6 (1992), 360–366).

problem_text:
3.62. (Well-known problem). A finite group is said to be a Dπ-group if any two of its maximal π-subgroups are conjugate. Is an extension of a Dπ-group by a Dπ-group always a Dπ-group?
L. A. Shemetkov
answer: Yes, it is mod CFSG (E. P. Vdovin, D. O. Revin, Contemp. Math., 402 (2006), 229–263).

problem_text:
Describe the finite simple groups with a Sylow 2-subgroup of the following type: ⟨a, t | a2n = t2 = 1, tat = a2n−1−1⟩, n > 2.
V. P. Shunkov
answer: This was done (J. L. Alperin, R. Brauer, D. Gorenstein, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc., 151 (1970), 1–261).

problem_text:
Find an infinite finitely generated group with an identical relation of the form x2n = 1.
S. I. Adian
answer: It has been found (S. V. Ivanov, Int. J. Algebra Comput., 4, no. 1–2 (1994), 1–308; I. G. Lys¨enok, Izv. Math., 60, no. 3 (1996), 453–654).

problem_text:
Construct a finitely presented group with insoluble word problem and satisfying a non-trivial law.
S. I. Adian
answer: This has been done (O. G. Kharlampovich, Math. USSR–Izv., 19 (1982), 151–169).

problem_text:
Construct a finitely presented group with undecidable word problem all of whose non-trivial defining relations have the form A2 = 1. This problem is interesting for topologists.
S. I. Adian
answer: It is constructed (O. A. Sarkisyan, The word problem for some classes of groups and semigroups, Candidate disser., Moscow Univ., 1983 (Russian)).

problem_text:
a) (J. Milnor). Is it true that an arbitrary finitely generated group has either polynomial or exponential growth?

c) Is it true that every finitely generated group with undecidable word problem has exponential growth?

S. I. Adian
answer: a) No, c) No (R. I. Grigorchuk, Soviet Math. Dokl., 28 (1983), 23–26).

problem_text:
Suppose G is a finitely generated free-by-cyclic group. Is G finitely presented?

G. Baumslag
answer: Yes, it is; moreover, every finitely generated subgroup is finitely presented. For infinite cyclic extensions this is proved in (M. Feighn, M. Handel, Ann. Math., 149, no. 3 (1999), 1061–1077), while another easier argument applies for finite cyclic extensions.

problem_text:
A group G is called locally indicable if every non-trivial finitely generated subgroup of G has an infinite cyclic factor group. Is every torsion-free one-relator group locally indicable?

G. Baumslag
answer: Yes, it is (S. D. Brodski˘ı, Dep. no. 2214-80, VINITI, Moscow, 1980 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Let G be a finite group and A a group of automorphisms of G stabilizing a series of subgroups beginning with G and ending with its Frattini subgroup. Then is A nilpotent?

Ya. G. Berkovich
answer: Yes, it is (P. Schmid, Math. Ann., 202 (1973), 57–69).

problem_text:
Let p be a prime number. What are necessary and sufficient conditions for a finite group G in order that the group algebra of G over a field of characteristic p be indecomposable as a two-sided ideal? There exist some nontrivial examples, for instance, the group algebra of the Mathieu group M24 is indecomposable when p is 2.

R. Brauer
answer: A necessary and sufficient condition can be extracted from (G. R. Robinson, J. Algebra, 84 (1983), 493–502); another solution, which requires considering fewer subgroups, can be extracted from (B. K¨ulshammer, Arch. Math. (Basel), 56 (1991), 313–319).

problem_text:
Suppose that K is a class of groups meeting the following requirements: 1) subgroups and epimorphic images of K-groups are K-groups; 2) if the group G = UV is the product of K-subgroups U and V (neither of which need be normal), then G ∈K. If π is a set of primes, then the class of all finite π-groups meets these requirements. Are these the only classes K with these properties?

R. Baer
answer: No (S. A. Syskin, Siberian Math. J., 20 (1979), 475–476).

problem_text:
a) Let F be a free group, and N a normal subgroup of it. Is it true that the Cartesian square of N is m-reducible to N (that is, there is an algorithm that from a pair of words w1, w2 ∈F constructs a word w ∈F such that w1 ∈N and w2 ∈N if and only if w ∈N)?

b) (Well-known problem). Do there exist finitely presented groups in which the word problem has an arbitrary pre-assigned recursively enumerable m-degree of unsolvability?

M. K. Valiev
answer:
a) No, it is not true (O. V. Belegradek, Siberian Math. J., 19 (1978), 867–870).

b) No, there exist m-degrees which do not contain the word problem of any recursively presented cancellation semigroup (C. G. Jockusch, jr., Z. Math. Logik Grundlag. Math., 26, no. 1 (1980), 93–95).

problem_text: Let G be a finite group, p an odd prime number, and P a Sylow p-subgroup of G. Let the order of every non-identity normal subgroup of G be divisible by p. Suppose P has an element x that is conjugate to no other from P. Does x belong to the centre of G? For p = 2, the answer is positive (G. Glauberman, J. Algebra, 4 (1966), 403–420). G. Glauberman
answer: Yes, it does, mod CFSG (O. D. Artemovich, Ukrain. Math. J., 40 (1988), 343–345).

problem_text: (J. G. Thompson). Let G be a finite group, A a group of automorphisms of G such that |A| and |G| are coprime. Does there exist an A-invariant soluble subgroup H of G such that CA(H) = 1? G. Glauberman
answer: Yes, it does (S. A. Syskin, Siberian Math. J., 32, no. 6 (1991), 1034–1037).

problem_text: Let G be a finite simple group, τ some element of prime order, and α an automorphism of G whose order is coprime to |G|. Suppose α centralizes CG(τ). Is α = 1? G. Glauberman
answer: Not always; for example, G = Sz(8), |τ| = 5, |α| = 3 (N. D. Podufalov, Letter of September, 3, 1975).

problem_text:
Suppose that T is a non-abelian Sylow 2-subgroup of a finite simple group G.
 b) Is it possible that T is the direct product of two proper subgroups?
 c) Is T ′ = Φ(T)?
D. Goldschmidt
answer:
b) Yes, it is. For example, the Sylow 2-subgroups of the alternating groups A14 and A15 are isomorphic to the Sylow 2-subgroup of S4 × S8. The Sylow 2-subgroups of D4(q) for q odd are also decomposable into direct products (A. S. Kondratiev, Letter of October, 13, 1977).
 c) Not always; for example, for G = PSL3(q) with q ≡1 (mod 4) (A. S. Kondratiev).

problem_text: Describe all finite simple groups G which can be represented in the form G = ABA, where A and B are abelian subgroups. I. P. Doktorov
answer: They are described mod CFSG (D. L. Zagorin, L. S. Kazarin, Dokl. Math., 53, no. 2 (1996), 237–239; D. L. Zagorin, Some problems of ABA-factorizations of permutation groups and classical groups (Cand. Diss.), Yaroslavl’, 1994 (Russian); D. L. Zagorin, L. S. Kazarin, Problems in algebra, Gomel’ Univ., Gomel’, no. 11 (1997), 27–41 (Russian); E. P. Vdovin, Algebra and Logic, 38, no. 2 (1999), 67–83).

problem_text: For a given field k of characteristic p > 0, characterize the locally finite groups with semisimple group algebras over k. A. E. Zalesskii
answer: They are characterized: simple groups in (D. S. Passman, A. E. Zalesskii, Proc. London Math. Soc. (3), 67 (1993), 243–276); the general case in (D. S. Passman, Proc. London Math. Soc. (3), 73 (1996), 323–357).

problem_text: Classify the irreducible matrix groups over a finite field that are generated by reflections, that is, by matrices with Jordan form diag(−1, 1, . . . , 1). A. E. Zalesski˘ı
answer: These are classified (A. E. Zalesski˘ı, V. N. Ser¨ezhkin, Math. USSR–Izv., 17 (1981), 477–503; A. Wagner, Geom. Dedicata, 9 (1980), 239–253; 10 (1981), 191–203, 475-523).

problem_text: The conjugacy problem for metabelian groups. M. I. Kargapolov
answer: This is algorithmically soluble (G. A. Noskov, Math. Notes, 31 (1982), 252–258).

problem_text:
(Well-known problem). Is there an infinite locally finite simple group satisfying the minimum condition for p-subgroups for every prime p?
O. H. Kegel
answer: No (V. V. Belyaev, Algebra and Logic, 20 (1981), 393–401).

problem_text:
Is there an infinite locally finite simple group G with an involution i such that the centralizer CG(i) is a Chernikov group?
O. H. Kegel
answer: No (A. O. Asar, Proc. London Math. Soc., 45 (1982), 337–364).

problem_text:
Is there an infinite locally finite simple group G that cannot be represented by matrices over a field and is such that for some prime p the p-subgroups of G are either of bounded derived length or of finite exponent?
O. H. Kegel
answer: No (mod CFSG) by Theorem 4.8 of (O. H. Kegel, B. A. F. Wehrfritz, Locally finite groups, North Holland, Amsterdam, 1973).

problem_text:
Classify the composition factors of automorphism groups of finite (nilpotent of class 2) groups of prime exponent.
V. D. Mazurov
answer: Any finite simple group can be such a composition factor (P. M. Beletski˘ı, Russian Math. Surveys, 33, no. 6 (1980), 85–86).

problem_text:
A countable group U is said to be SQ-universal if every countable group is isomorphic to a subgroup of a quotient group of U. Let G be a group that has a presentation with r ⩾ 2 generators and at most r − 2 defining relations. Is G SQ-universal?
A. M. Macbeath, P. M. Neumann
answer: Yes, it is (B. Baumslag, S. J. Pride, J. London Math. Soc., 17 (1978), 425–426).

problem_text:
A point z in the complex plane is called free if the matrices
( 1  2 ; 0  1 )
and
( 1  0 ; z  1 )
generate a free group. Are all points outside the rhombus with vertices ±2, ±i free?
Yu. I. Merzlyakov
answer: No (Yu. A. Ignatov, Math. USSR–Sb., 35 (1979), 49–56; A. I. Shkuratski˘ı, Math. Notes, 24 (1978), 720–721).

problem_text:
Let G be a free product amalgamating proper subgroups H and K of A and B, respectively.
 a) Suppose that H, K are finite and |A : H| > 2, |B : K| ⩾ 2. Is G SQ-universal?
 b) Suppose that A, B, H, K are free groups of finite ranks. Can G be simple?
P. M. Neumann
answer:
a) Yes, it is (K. I. Lossov, Siberian Math. J., 27, no. 6 (1986), 890–899).
 b) Yes, it can (M. Burger, S. Mozes, Inst. Hautes ´Etudes Sci. Publ. Math., 92 (2000), 151–194). But if one of the indices |A : H|, |B : K| is infinite, then no, it cannot (S. V. Ivanov, P. E. Schupp, in: Algorithmic problems in groups and semigroups, Int. Conf., Lincoln, NE, 1998, Boston MA, Birkh¨auser, 2000, 139–142).

problem_text:
b) We call a variety of groups a limit variety if it cannot be defined by finitely many laws, while each of its proper subvarieties has a finite basis of identities. It follows from Zorn’s lemma that every variety that has no finite basis of identities contains a limit subvariety. Is the set of limit varieties countable?
A. Yu. Olshanskii
answer: No, there are continuum of such varieties (P. A. Kozhevnikov, On varieties of groups of large odd exponent, Dep. 1612-V00, VINITI, Moscow, 2000 (Russian); S. V. Ivanov, A. M. Storozhev, Contemp. Math., 360 (2004), 55–62).

problem_text:
Does there exist a countable family of groups such that every variety is generated by a subfamily of it?
A. Yu. Olshanskii
answer: No (Yu. G. Kleiman, Math. USSR–Izv., 22 (1984), 33–65).

problem_text:
Let G and H be finitely generated torsion-free nilpotent groups such that Aut G ∼= Aut H. Does it follow that G ∼= H?
V. N. Remeslennikov
answer: No (G. A. Noskov, V. A. Roman’kov, Algebra and Logic, 13 (1974), 306–311).

problem_text:
(Well-known problem). Are knot groups residually finite?
V. N. Remeslennikov
answer: Yes, they are (W. P. Thurston, Bull. Amer. Math. Soc., 6 (1982), 357–381).

problem_text:
Let G be a finitely generated torsion-free group that is an extension of an abelian group by a nilpotent group. Then is G almost a residually finite p-group for almost all primes p?
V. N. Remeslennikov
answer: Yes, it is (G. A. Noskov, Algebra and Logic, 13 (1974), 388–393; D. Segal, J. Algebra, 32 (1974), 389–399).

problem_text:
P. F. Pickel has proved that there are only finitely many non-isomorphic finitely-generated nilpotent groups having the same family of finite homomorphic images. Can Pickel’s theorem be extended to polycyclic groups?
V. N. Remeslennikov
answer: Yes, it can (F. J. Grunewald, P. F. Pickel, D. Segal, Ann. of Math. (2), 111 (1980), 155–195).

problem_text:
Are any two minimal relation-modules of a finite group isomorphic?
K. W. Roggenkamp
answer: Not always (P. A. Linnell, Ph. D. Thesis, Cambridge, 1979; A. J. Sieradski, M. N. Dyer, J. Pure Appl. Algebra, 15 (1979), 199–217).

problem_text:
Let a group G be the product of two of its abelian minimax subgroups A and B. Prove or refute the following statements:
a) A0B0 ̸= 1, where A0 = T x∈G Ax and similarly for B0;
b) the derived subgroup of G is a minimax subgroup.
N. F. Sesekin
answer: Both parts were proved (D. I. Zaitsev, Algebra and Logic, 19 (1980), 94–106).

problem_text:
Let a finite group G be the product of two subgroups A and B, where A is abelian and B is nilpotent. Find the dependence of the derived length of G on the nilpotency class of B and the order of its derived subgroup.
N. F. Sesekin
answer: This was found (D. I. Zaitsev, Math. Notes, 33 (1983), 414–419).

problem_text:
(P. Hall). Find the smallest positive integer n such that every countable group can be embedded in a simple group with n generators.
D. M. Smirnov
answer: It is proved that n = 2 (A. P. Goryushkin, Math. Notes, 16 (1974), 725–727).

problem_text:
(P. Hall). What is the cardinality of the set of simple groups generated by two elements, one of order 2 and the other of order 3?
D. M. Smirnov
answer: The cardinality of the continuum. Every 2-generated group G is embeddable into a simple group H with two generators of orders 2 and 3 (P. E. Schupp, J. London Math. Soc., 13, no. 1 (1976), 90–94). Such a group H has at most countably many 2-generator subgroups, while there are continuum of groups G. (Yu. I. Merzlyakov, 1976.)

problem_text:
Does there exist a linear function f with the following property: if every abelian subgroup of a finite 2-group G is generated by n elements, then G is generated by f(n) elements?
S. A. Syskin
answer: No (A. Yu. Olshanskii, Math. Notes, 23 (1978), 183–185).

problem_text:
Does there exist a finitely based variety of groups whose universal theory is undecidable?
A. Tarski
answer:
Yes, there does; for example, A5. Indeed, it is shown in (V. N. Remeslennikov, Algebra and Logic, 12, no. 5 (1975), 327–346) that there exists a finitely presented group
G = ⟨x1, . . . , xn | w1, . . . , wm, mod A5⟩
in A5 with undecidable word problem. We put Φw = (∀x1, . . . , xn)((w1 = 1) ∧ . . . ∧ (wm = 1) → (w = 1)), where w runs over all the words in x1, . . . , xn. Clearly, there is no algorithm to decide whether a formula Φw is true in A5. (V. N. Remeslennikov, 1976.)

problem_text:
Does there exist a non-abelian variety of groups (in particular, one that contains the variety of all abelian groups) whose elementary theory is decidable?
A. Tarski
answer: No (A. P. Zamyatin, Algebra and Logic, 27 (1978), 13–17).

problem_text:
Does there exist a variety of groups that does not admit an independent system of defining identities?
A. Tarski
answer: Yes, there does (Yu. G. Kleiman, Math. USSR–Izv., 22 (1984), 33–65).

problem_text:
Let G be a finite p-group. Show that the rank of the multiplicator M(G) of G is bounded in terms of the rank of G.
J. Wiegold
answer: This was done (A. Lubotzky, A. Mann, J. Algebra, 105 (1987), 484–505).

problem_text:
Construct a finitely generated (infinite) characteristically simple group that is not a direct power of a simple group.
J. Wiegold
answer: This was done (J. S. Wilson, Math. Proc. Cambridge Phil. Soc., 80 (1976), 19–35).

problem_text:
Let G be a finite p-group, and suppose that |G′| > p^{n(n−1)/2} for some non-negative integer n. Prove that G is generated by the elements of breadths ⩾ n. The breadth of an element x of G is b(x) where |G : CG(x)| = p^{b(x)}.
J. Wiegold
answer: This has been proved (A. Skutin, J. Algebra, 526 (2019), 1–5).

problem_text:
Let k be a field of characteristic different from 2, and Gk the group of transformations A = (a, α) : x → ax + α (a, α ∈ k, a ≠ 0). Extend Gk to the projective plane by adjoining the symbols (0, α) and a line at infinity. Then the lines are just the centralizers CG(A) of elements A ∈ Gk and their cosets. Do there exist other groups G complementable to the projective plane such that the lines are just the cosets of the centralizers of elements of G?
H. Schwerdtfeger
answer: No (E. A. Kuznetsov, Dep. no. 7028-V89, VINITI, Moscow, 1989 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Let A be a group of automorphisms of a finite group G which has a series of A-invariant subgroups G = G0 > · · · > Gk = 1 such that every |Gi : Gi+1| is prime. Prove that A is supersoluble.
L. A. Shemetkov
answer: This was proved (L. A. Shemetkov, Math. USSR–Sb., 23 (1974), 593–611).

problem_text:
(Well-known problem). Does there exist a non-abelian variety of groups
a) all of whose finite groups are abelian?
b) all of whose periodic groups are abelian?
A. L. Shmel’kin
answer:
a) Yes, there does (A. Yu. Olshanskii, Math. USSR–Sb., 54 (1986), 57–80).
b) Yes, there does (P. A. Kozhevnikov, On varieties of groups of large odd exponent, Dep. 1612-V00, VINITI, Moscow, 2000 (Russian); S. V. Ivanov, A. M. Storozhev, Contemp. Math., 360 (2004), 55–62).

problem_text:
a) Is every 2-group of order greater than 2 non-simple?
V. P. Shunkov
answer: No, the existence of simple infinite 2-groups follows from the existence of finitely generated infinite groups of exponent 2n (S. V. Ivanov, Int. J. Algebra Comput., 4, no. 1–2 (1994), 1–308; I. G. Lys¨enok, Izv. Math., 60, no. 3 (1996), 453–654) and from the positive solution to the Restricted Burnside Problem for groups of exponent 2n (E. I. Zel’manov, Math. USSR–Sb., 72 (1992), 543–565).

problem_text:
Let G be a locally finite group containing an element a of prime order such that the centralizer CG(a) is finite. Is G almost soluble?
V. P. Shunkov
answer: Yes, it is. P. Fong (Osaka J. Math., 13 (1976), 483–489) has shown (mod CFSG) that G is almost locally soluble. Given this, B. Hartley and T. Meixner (Arch. Math., 36 (1981), 211–213) have proved that G is almost locally nilpotent. Therefore G is almost soluble by (J. L. Alperin, Proc. Amer. Math. Soc., 13 (1962), 175–180) and (G. Higman, J. London Math. Soc., 32 (1957), 321–334). Moreover, by (E. I. Khukhro, Math. Notes, 38, no. 5-6 (1985), 867–870; E. I. Khukhro, Math. USSR–Sb., 71, no. 1 (1992), 51–63) then G is almost nilpotent.

problem_text:
In 1972, A. Rudvalis discovered a new simple group R of order 214·33·53·7·13·29. He has shown that R possesses an involution i such that CR(i) = V × F, where V is a 4-group (an elementary abelian group of order 4) and F ∼= Sz(8).
a) Show that R is the only finite simple group G that possesses an involution i such that CG(i) = V × F, where V is a 4-group and F ∼= Sz(8).
b) Let G be a non-abelian finite simple group that possesses an involution i such that CG(i) = V × F, where V is an elementary abelian 2-group of order 2n, n ⩾1, and F ∼= Sz(2m), m ⩾3. Show that n = 2 and m = 3.
Z. Janko
answer:
a) This has been shown (V. D. Mazurov, Math. Notes, 31 (1982), 165–173).
b) This follows from the CFSG.

problem_text:
a) Is every locally finite minimal non-FC-group non-simple?
V. V. Belyaev, N. F. Sesekin
answer: Yes, it is (M. Kuzucuo¯glu, R. E. Phillips, Proc. Cambridge Philos. Soc., 105, no. 3 (1989), 417–420).

problem_text:
Is it true that the growth function f of any infinite finitely generated group satisfies the inequality f(n) ⩽ (f(n −1) + f(n + 1))/2 for all sufficiently large n (for a fixed finite system of generators)?
V. V. Belyaev, N. F. Sesekin
answer: No (P. de la Harpe, R. I. Grigorchuk, Algebra and Logic, 37, no. 6 (1998), 353–356).

problem_text:
Can every finite lattice L be embedded in the lattice of subgroups of a finite group?
G. M. Bergman
answer: Yet, it can (P. Pudl´ak, J. T°uma, Algebra Universalis, 10 (1980), 74–95).

problem_text:
Let g and h be positive elements of a linearly ordered group G. Can one always embed G in a linearly ordered group G in such a way that g and h are conjugate in G?
V. V. Bludov
answer: No, not always (V. V. Bludov, Algebra and Logic, 44, no. 6 (2005), 370–380).

problem_text:
If R is a finitely generated integral domain of characteristic p > 0, does the profinite (ideal) topology of R induce the profinite topology on the group of units of R? It does for p = 0.
B. A. F. Wehrfritz
answer: Yes, it does (D. Segal, Bull. London Math. Soc., 11 (1979), 186–190).

problem_text:
An algebraic variety X over a field k is called rational if the field of functions k(X) is purely transcendental over k, and it is called stably rational if k(X) becomes purely transcendental after adjoining finitely many independent variables. Let T be a stably rational torus over a field k. Is T rational? Other formulations of this question and some related results see in (V. E. Voskresenski˘ı, Russ. Math. Surveys, 28, no. 4 (1973), 79–105).
V. E. Voskresenski˘ı
answer: Yes, it is (V. E. Voskresenskii, J. Math. Sci. (N. Y.), 161, no. 1 (2009), 176–180).

problem_text:
Let G be a torsion-free soluble group of finite cohomological dimension cd G. If hG denotes the Hirsch number of G, then it is known that hG ⩽ cd G ⩽ hG+1. Find a purely group-theoretic criterion for hG = cd G.
K. W. Gruenberg
answer: This has been found (P. H. Kropholler, J. Pure Appl. Algebra, 43 (1986), 281–287).

problem_text:
Let 1 → Ri πi −→ F → G →1, i = 1, 2, be two exact sequences of groups with G finite and F free of finite rank d(F). If we assume that d(F) = d(G) + 1 (where d(G) is the minimum number of generators of G), are the corresponding abelianized extensions isomorphic?
K. W. Gruenberg
answer: Yes, they are (P. A. Linnell, J. Pure Appl. Algebra, 22 (1981), 143–166).

problem_text:
Let E = H ∗ K and denote the augmentation ideals of the groups E, H, K by e, h, k, respectively. If I is a right ideal in ZE, let dE(I) denote the minimum number of generators of I as a right ideal. Assuming H and K finitely generated, is it true that dE(e) = dE(hE) + dE(kE)? Here hE is, of course, the right ideal generated by h; similarly for kE.
K. W. Gruenberg
answer:
Not always (P. A. Linnell, unpublished). A simple example: H is elementary abelian group of order 4, K is elementary abelian of order 9.
Here dE(e) = 3, although dE(hE) = dE(kE) = 2. (K. W. Gruenberg, Letter of July, 27, 1995.)

problem_text:
Let G be a finite group and suppose that there exists a non-empty proper subset π of the set of all primes dividing |G| such that the centralizer of every non-trivial π-element is a π-subgroup. Does it follow that G contains a subgroup U such that U^g ∩ U = 1 or U for every g ∈ G, and the centralizer of every non-trivial element of U is contained in U?
K. W. Gruenberg
answer: Yes, it does (mod CFSG) (J. S. Williams, J. Algebra, 69 (1981), 487–513).

problem_text: Let G be a finite group with trivial soluble radical in which there are Sylow 2-subgroups having non-trivial intersection. Suppose that, for any two Sylow 2-subgroups P and Q of G with P ∩ Q ≠ 1, the index |P : P ∩ Q| does not exceed 2n. Is it then true that |P| ⩽ 2^{2n}? V. V. Kabanov
answer: Yes, it is, mod CFSG (V. I. Zenkov, Algebra and Logic, 36, no. 2 (1997), 93–98).

problem_text: Suppose that K and L are distinct conjugacy classes of involutions in a finite group G and ⟨x, y⟩ is a 2-group for all x ∈ K and y ∈ L. Does it follow that G ≠ [K, L]? V. V. Kabanov
answer: Not always; for example, G = Sp4(2n), n ⩾ 2, K, L being classes of involutions that have non-trivial intersections with the centres of NG(M)′ and NG(N)′, respectively, where M, N are distinct elementary abelian subgroups of order 8 in a Sylow 2-subgroup of G and the dash means taking the derived subgroup (A. A. Makhn¨ev, Letter of October, 10, 1981).

problem_text: If the finite group G has the form G = AB where A and B are nilpotent of classes α and β, respectively, then G is soluble. Is G(α+β) = 1? One can show that G(α+β) is nilpotent (E. Pennington, 1973). One can ask the same question for infinite groups (or Lie algebras), but there is nothing known beyond Ito’s theorem: A′ = B′ = 1 implies G(2) = 1. O. H. Kegel
answer: Not always (J. Cossey, S. Stonehewer, Bull. London Math. Soc., 30, no. 144 (1998), 247–250). See also new problem 14.43.

problem_text: Let G be an infinite locally finite simple group. Is the centralizer of every element of G infinite? O. H. Kegel
answer: Yes, it is (B. Hartley, M. Kuzucuo¯glu, Proc. London Math. Soc. (3), 62, no. 2 (1991), 301–324).

problem_text:
a) Let G be an infinite locally finite simple group satisfying the minimum condition for 2-subgroups. Is G = PSL2(F), F some locally finite field of odd characteristic, if the centralizer of every involution of G is almost locally soluble?

b) Can one characterize the simple locally finite groups with the min-2 condition containing a maximal radical non-trivial 2-subgroup of rank ⩽ 2 as linear groups of small rank? O. H. Kegel
answer:
a) Yes, it is (N. S. Chernikov, Ukrain. Math. J., 35 (1983), 230–231).

b) Yes, one can (mod CFSG) by Theorem 4.8 of (O. H. Kegel, B. A. F. Wehrfritz, Locally finite groups, North Holland, Amsterdam, 1973).

problem_text: Is the elementary theory of lattices of l-ideals of lattice-ordered abelian groups decidable? A. I. Kokorin
answer: No, it is undecidable (N. Ya. Medvedev, Algebra and Logic, 44, no. 5 (2005), 302–312).

problem_text: Can every torsion-free group with solvable word problem be embedded in a group with solvable conjugacy problem? An example due to A. Macintyre shows that this question has a negative answer when the condition of torsion-freeness is omitted. D. J. Collins
answer: No, not every (A. Darbinyan, Invent. Math., 224 (2021), 987–997).

problem_text:
Does there exist a version of the Higman embedding theorem in which the degree of unsolvability of the conjugacy problem is preserved?
D. J. Collins
answer: Yes, there does (A. Yu. Olshanskii, M. V. Sapir, The conjugacy problem and Higman embeddings (Memoirs AMS, 804), 2004, 133 p.).

problem_text:
Is it true that a free lattice-ordered group of the variety of lattice-ordered groups defined by the law x−1|y|x ≪|y|2 (or, equivalently, by the law |[x, y]| ≪|x|), is residually linearly ordered nilpotent?
V. M. Kopytov
answer: No, it is not (V. V. Bludov, A. M. W. Glass, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc., 358 (2006), 5179–5192).

problem_text:
Is it true that a free lattice-ordered group of the variety of the lattice-ordered groups which are residually linearly ordered, is residually soluble linearly ordered?
V. M. Kopytov
answer: No, it is not (N. Ya. Medvedev, Algebra and Logic, 44, no. 3 (2005), 197–204).

problem_text:
Let G be a group and H a torsion-free subgroup of G such that the augmentation ideal IG of the integral group-ring ZG can be decomposed as IG = IHZG ⊕M for some ZG-submodule M. Prove that G is a free product of the form G = H ∗K.
D. E. Cohen
answer: This has been proved (W. Dicks, M. J. Dunwoody, Groups acting on graphs, Cambridge Univ. Press, Cambridge–New York, 1989).

problem_text:
Consider a group G given by a presentation with m generators and n defining relations, where m ⩾n.
Do some m −n of the given generators generate a free subgroup of G?
R. C. Lyndon
answer: Yes, they do (N. S. Romanovski˘ı, Algebra and Logic, 16 (1977), 62–68).

problem_text:
Let p be a prime, C a conjugacy class of p-elements of a finite group G and suppose that for any two elements x and y of C the product xy−1 is a p-element. Is the subgroup generated by the class C a p-group?
V. D. Mazurov
answer: Yes, it is (for p > 2: W. Xiao, Sci. in China, 34, no. 9 (1991), 1025–1031; for p = 2: V. I. Zenkov, in: Algebra. Proc. IIIrd Int. Conf. on Algebra, Krasnoyarsk, 1993, Berlin, De Gruyter, 1996, 297–302).

problem_text:
Let o be a commutative ring with identity in which 2 is invertible and which is not generated by zero divisors. Do there exist non–standard automorphisms of GLn(o) for n ⩾3?
Yu. I. Merzlyakov
answer: No (V. Ya. Bloshchitsyn, Algebra and Logic, 17 (1978), 415–417).

problem_text:
Let G be a countable group acting on a set Ω. Suppose that G is k-fold transitive for every finite k, and G contains no non-trivial permutations of finite support. Is it true that Ω can be identified with the rational line Q in such a way that G becomes a group of autohomeomorphisms?
P. M. Neumann
answer: Not always (A. H. Mekler, J. London Math. Soc., 33 (1986), 49–58).

problem_text:
Does every non-trivial finite group, which is free in some variety, contain a non-trivial abelian normal subgroup?
A. Yu. Olshanskii
answer: Yes, it does (mod CFSG). Otherwise, if G is a counterexample, the centralizer of the product E of all minimal normal subgroups of G is trivial and there is an element of G/E whose order is m, where m is the maximum of the orders of 2-elements of G. By Theorem 1 in (M. Aschbacher, P. B. Kleidman, M. W. Liebeck, Math. Z., 208, no. 3 (1991), 401–409), which is proved using CFSG, there is an element of order 2m in G, which contradicts the choice of m. (S. A. Syskin, Letter of August, 20, 1992.)

problem_text:
Does there exist a soluble variety of groups that is not generated by its finite groups?
A. Yu. Olshanskii
answer: Yes, there does (Yu. G. Kleiman, Trans. Moscow Math. Soc., 1983, no. 2, 63–110).

problem_text:
Is every recursively presented soluble group embeddable in a group finitely presented in the variety of all soluble groups of derived length n, for suitable n?
V. N. Remeslennikov
answer: Yes, it is (G. P. Kukin, Soviet Math. Dokl., 21 (1980), 378–381).

problem_text:
Let Am,n be the group of all automorphisms of the free soluble group of derived length n and rank m. Is it true that
a) Am,n is finitely generated for any m and n?
b) every automorphism in Am,n is induced by some automorphism in Am,n+1?
V. N. Remeslennikov
answer:
a) No: A3,2 is not finitely generated, although Am,2 is whenever m ̸= 3 (S. Bachmuth, H. Y. Mochizuki, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc., 270 (1982), 693–700, 292 (1985), 81–101).
b) No (V. Shpilrain, Int. J. Algebra and Comput., 1, no. 2 (1991), 177–184).

problem_text:
Is there a finite group whose set of quasi-laws does not have an independent basis?
D. M. Smirnov
answer: Yes, there is (A. N. Fedorov, Siberian Math. J., 21 (1980), 840–850).

problem_text:
Does a non-abelian free group have an independent basis for its quasi-laws?
D. M. Smirnov
answer: Yes, it does (A. I. Budkin, Math. Notes, 31 (1982), 413–417).

problem_text:
(P. Scott). Let p, q, r be distinct prime numbers. Prove that the free product G = Cp ∗Cq ∗Cr of cyclics of orders p, q, r is not the normal closure of a single element. By Lemma 3.1 of (J. Wiegold, J. Austral. Math. Soc., 17, no. 2 (1974), 133–141), every soluble image, and every finite image, of G is the normal closure of a single element.
J. Wiegold
answer: This is proved in (J. Howie, J. Pure Appl. Algebra, 173, no. 2 (2002), 167–176).

problem_text:
5.56. b) Does there exist a locally nilpotent group of prime exponent that coincides with its derived subgroup (and hence has no maximal subgroups)?
J. Wiegold
answer: Yes, there does. Every non-soluble variety V contains a non-trivial group coinciding with the derived subgroup, the direct limit of the spectrum F φ→F φ→. . ., where F is the free group in V on the free generators x1, x2, . . . and φ is the homomorphism given by xi →[x2i−1, x2i]. As shown in (Yu. P. Razmyslov, Algebra and Logic, 10 (1971), 21–29) the Kostrikin variety of locally nilpotent groups of prime exponent p ⩾5 is unsoluble. (E. I. Khukhro, I. V. L’vov, Letter of June, 19, 1976.) The same was also proved in (Yu. A. Kolmakov, Math. Notes, 35, no. 5–6 (1984), 389–391). An example answering the question was also produced in (M. R. Vaughan-Lee, J. Wiegold, Bull. London Math. Soc., 13, no. 1 (1981), 45–46).

problem_text:
5.60. Is an arbitrary soluble group that satisfies the minimum condition for normal subgroups countable?
B. Hartley
answer: Not always (B. Hartley, Proc. London Math. Soc., 33 (1977), 55–75).

problem_text:
5.61. (Well-known problem). Does an arbitrary uncountable locally finite group have only one end?
B. Hartley
answer: Yes, it does (D. Holt, Bull. London Math. Soc., 13 (1981), 557–560).

problem_text:
5.62. Is a group locally finite if it contains infinite abelian subgroups and all of them are complementable?
S. N. Chernikov
answer: Not always (N. S. Chernikov, Math. Notes, 28 (1980), 788–792).

problem_text:
5.63. Prove that a finite group is not simple if it contains two non-identity elements whose centralizers have coprime indices.
S. A. Chunikhin
answer: This has been proved mod CFSG (L. S. Kazarin, in: Studies in Group Theory, Sverdlovsk, 1984, 81–99 (Russian)).

problem_text:
5.64. Suppose that a finite group G is the product of two subgroups A1 and A2. Prove that if Ai contains a nilpotent subgroup of index ⩽2 for i = 1, 2, then G is soluble.
L. A. Shemetkov
answer: This has been proved (L. S. Kazarin, Math. USSR–Sb., 38 (1981), 47–59).

problem_text:
5.65. Is the class of all finite groups that have Hall π-subgroups closed under taking finite subdirect products?
L. A. Shemetkov
answer: Yes, it is (D. O. Revin, E. P. Vdovin, J. Group Theory, 14, no. 1 (2011), 93–101).

problem_text:
5.68. Let G be a finitely-presented group, and assume that G has polynomial growth in the sense of Milnor. Show that G has soluble word problem.
P. E. Schupp
answer: This has been shown (M. Gromov, Publ. Math. IHES, 53 (1981), 53–73).

problem_text:
5.69. Is every lattice isomorphism between torsion-free groups having no non-trivial cyclic normal subgroups induced by a group isomorphism?
B. V. Yakovlev
answer: No (A. Yu. Olshanskii, C. R. Acad. Bulgare Sci., 32 (1979), 1165–1166).

problem_text:
6.4. A group G is called of type (FP)∞if the trivial G-module Z has a resolution by finitely generated projective G-modules. Is it true that every torsion-free group of type (FP)∞has finite cohomological dimension?
R. Bieri
answer: No (K. S. Brown, R. Geoghegan, Invent. Math., 77 (1984), 367–381).

problem_text: Let P, Q be permutation representations of a finite group G with the same character. Suppose P(G) is a primitive permutation group. Is Q(G) necessarily primitive? The answer is known to be affirmative if G is soluble. H. Wielandt
answer: No, not necessarily (mod CFSG) (R. M. Guralnick, J. Saxl, in: Groups, Combinatorics, Geometry, Proc. Durham, 1990, Cambridge Univ. Press, 1992, 364–367).

problem_text: Suppose that P is a finite 2-group. Does there exist a characteristic subgroup L(P) of P such that L(P) is normal in H for every finite group H that satisfies the following conditions: 1) P is a Sylow 2-subgroup of H, 2) H is S4-free, and 3) CH(O2(H)) ⩽ O2(H)? G. Glauberman
answer: Yes, there does (B. Stellmacher, Israel J. Math., 94 (1996), 367–379).

problem_text: Can a residually finite locally normal group be embedded in a Cartesian product of finite groups in such a way that each element of the group has at most finitely many central projections? Yu. M. Gorchakov
answer: Yes, it can (M. J. Tomkinson, Bull. London Math. Soc., 13 (1981), 133–137).

problem_text: a) Is a metabelian group countable if it satisfies the weak minimum condition for normal subgroups? b) Is such a group minimax if it is torsion-free? D. I. Zaitsev
answer: Yes, it is, in both cases (D. I. Zaitsev, L. A. Kurdachenko, A. V. Tushev, Algebra and Logic, 24 (1985), 412–436).

problem_text: Is it true that if a non-abelian Sylow 2-subgroup of a finite group G has a non-trivial abelian direct factor, then G is not simple? A. S. Kondratiev
answer: Yes, it is, mod CFSG (V. V. Kabanov, A. S. Kondratiev, Sylow 2-subgroups of finite groups (a survey), Inst. Math. Mech. UNC AN SSSR, Sverdlovsk, 1979 (Russian)).

problem_text: Are the following lattices locally finite: the lattice of all locally finite varieties of groups? the lattice of all varieties of groups? A. V. Kuznetsov
answer: No, they are not (M. I. Anokhin, Izv. Math., 63, no. 4 (1999), 649–665).

problem_text: A variety is said to be pro-locally-finite if it is not locally finite while all of its proper subvarieties are locally finite. An example — the variety of abelian groups. How many pro-locally-finite varieties of groups are there? A. V. Kuznetsov
answer: There are continuum of such varieties (P. A. Kozhevnikov, On varieties of groups of large odd exponent, Dep. 1612-V00, VINITI, Moscow, 2000 (Russian)).

problem_text: A variety is called sparse if it has at most countably many subvarieties. How many sparse varieties of groups are there? A. V. Kuznetsov
answer: There are continuum of such varieties (P. A. Kozhevnikov, On varieties of groups of large odd exponent, Dep. 1612-V00, VINITI, Moscow, 2000 (Russian); S. V. Ivanov, A. M. Storozhev, Contemp. Math., 360 (2004), 55–62).

problem_text: Is every variety of groups generated by its finitely generated groups that have soluble word problem? A. V. Kuznetsov
answer: No (Yu. G. Kleiman, Math. USSR–Izv., 22 (1984), 33–65).

problem_text: (Well-known problem). Suppose that a class K of 2-generator groups generates the variety of all groups. Is a non-cyclic free group residually in K? V. M. Levchuk
answer: Not always (S. J. Pride, Math. Z., 131 (1973), 245–248).

problem_text: Let R be a nilpotent associative ring. Are the following two statements for a subgroup H of the adjoint group of R always equivalent: 1) H is a normal subgroup; 2) H is an ideal of the groupoid R with respect to Lie multiplication? V. M. Levchuk
answer: Not always. Let R be the free nilpotent of index 3 associative algebra over F2 on the free generators x, y. Let S be the subalgebra generated by the elements [x, y2] = x∗y2, [x, xy] = x ∗(xy) = x(x ∗y), [x, yx] = x ∗(yx) = (x ∗y)x, where [a, b] denotes the commutator in the adjoint group with multiplication a ◦b = a + b + ab, and a ∗b = ab −ba is Lie multiplication. Let M, N be the subalgebras generated by S and the elements x ∗y and [x, y], respectively. The minimal subgroup of (R, ◦) that contains x and is an ideal of the groupoid (R, ∗) equals ⟨x⟩◦M = ⟨x⟩+ M, where ⟨x⟩= {0, x, x2, x+x2 +x3}, while the minimal normal subgroup containing x equals ⟨x⟩◦N = ⟨x⟩+ N. Neither is contained in the other. (E. I. Khukhro, Letter of July, 23, 1979.)

problem_text: Does there exist a supersoluble group of odd order, all of whose automorphisms are inner? V. D. Mazurov
answer: Yes, there does (B. Hartley, D. J. S. Robinson, Arch. Math., 35 (1980), 67–74).

problem_text: Construct a braid that belongs to the derived subgroup of the braid group but is not a commutator. G. S. Makanin
answer: Let x = σ1, y = σ2 be the standard generators of the braid group B3; then the braid (xyxyx)12(xy)−12(xyx)−12 belongs to the derived subgroup of B3 but is not a commutator (Yu. S. Sem¨enov, Abstracts of the 10th All-Union Sympos. on Group Theory, Minsk, 1986, p. 207 (Russian)).

problem_text: A braid K of the braid group Bn+1 is said to be smooth if removing any of the threads in K transforms K into a braid that is equal to 1 in Bn. It is known that smooth braids form a free subgroup. Describe generators of this subgroup. G. S. Makanin
answer: They are described in (D. L. Johnson, Math. Proc. Camb. Philos. Soc., 92 (1982), 425–427).

problem_text: (Well-known problem). Find an algorithm for calculating the rank of coefficient-free equations in a free group. The rank of an equation is the maximal rank of the free subgroup generated by a solution of this equation. G. S. Makanin
answer: This was found (A. A. Razborov, Math. USSR–Izv., 25 (1984), 115–162).

problem_text: a) Suppose that G is a finitely-generated residually-finite group, d(G) the minimal number of generators of G, and δ(G) the minimal number of topological generators of the profinite completion of G. Is δ(G) = d(G) always true? O. V. Mel’nikov
answer: Not always (G. A. Noskov, Math. Notes, 33 (1983), 249–254).

problem_text:
