Let o be an associative ring with identity. A system of its ideals A = {Aij | i, j ∈ Z} is called a carpet of ideals if AikAkj ⊆ Aij for all i, j, k ∈ Z. If o is commutative, then the set Γn(A) = {x ∈ SLn(o) | xij ≡ δij (mod Aij)} is a group, the (special) congruenz-subgroup modulo the carpet A (the “carpet subgroup”). Under quite general conditions, it was proved in (Yu. I. Merzlyakov, Algebra i Logika, 3, no. 4 (1964), 49–59 (Russian); see also M. I. Kargapolov, Yu. I. Merzlyakov, Fundamentals of the Theory of Groups, 3rd Ed., Moscow, Nauka, 1982, p. 145 (Russian)) that in the groups GLn and SLn the mutual commutator subgroup of the congruenz-subgroups modulo a carpet of ideals shifted by k and l steps is again the congruenz-subgroup modulo the same carpet shifted by k + l steps. Prove analogous theorems a) for orthogonal groups; b) for unitary groups.
Yu. I. Merzlyakov
answer: These are proved (V. M. Levchuk, Sov. Math. Dokl., 42, no. 1 (1991), 82–86; Ukrain. Math. J., 44, no. 6 (1992), 710–718).

problem_text:
(R. Bieri, R. Strebel). Let o be an associative ring with identity distinct from zero. A group G is said to be almost finitely presented over o if it has a presentation G = F/R where F is a finitely generated free group and the oG-module R/[R, R]⊗Z o is finitely generated. It is easy to see that every finitely presented group G is almost finitely presented over Z and therefore also over an arbitrary ring o. Is the converse true?
Yu. I. Merzlyakov
answer: No, it is not true (M. Bestvina, N. Brady, Invent. Math., 129, no. 3 (1997), 445–470).

problem_text:
(J. W. Grossman). The nilpotent-completion diagram of a group G is as follows: G/γ1G ← G/γ2G ← · · · , where γiG is the ith term of the lower central series and the arrows are natural homomorphisms. It is easy to see that every nilpotent-completion diagram G1 ← G2 ← · · · is a γ-diagram, that is, every sequence 1 → γsGs+1 → Gs+1 → Gs → 1, s = 1, 2, . . ., is exact. Do γ-diagrams exist that are not nilpotent-completion diagrams?
Yu. I. Merzlyakov
answer: Yes, such γ-diagrams exist (N. S. Romanovski˘ı, Sibirsk. Mat. Zh., 26, no. 4 (1985), 194–195 (Russian)).

problem_text:
(H. Wielandt, O. H. Kegel). Is a finite group G soluble if it has soluble subgroups A, B, C such that G = AB = AC = BC?
V. S. Monakhov
answer: Yes, it is (mod CFSG) (L. S. Kazarin, Ukrain. Math. J., 43 (1991), 883–886).

problem_text:
a) Let k be a (commutative) field. Find all irreducible subgroups G of GLn(k) having the property that G ∩ C ̸= ∅ for every conjugacy class C of GLn(k). I conjecture that G = GLn(k) except in case n = char k = 2, the field k is quadratically closed, and G is conjugate to the group of all matrices of the form
( α 0; 0 β ), ( 0 α; β 0 )
where α ̸= 0 and β ̸= 0.
P. M. Neumann
answer: a) The conjecture is refuted (S. A. Zyubin, Algebra and Logic, 45, no. 5 (2006), 296–305).

problem_text:
Let H be a strongly 3-embedded subgroup of a finite group G. Suppose that Z(H/O3′(H)) contains an element of order 3. Does Z(G/O3′(G)) necessarily contain an element of order 3?
N. D. Podufalov
answer: Yes, it does (mod CFSG) (W. Xiao, Sci. China (A), 33 (1990), 1172–1181).

problem_text:
Does the set of quasi-identities holding in the class of all finite groups possess a basis in finitely many variables?
D. M. Smirnov
answer: No (A. K. Rumyantsev, Algebra and Logic, 19 (1980), 297–311).

problem_text:
Construct a finitely generated infinite simple group requiring more than two generators.
J. Wiegold
answer: This has been done (V. S. Guba, Siberian Math. J., 27 (1986), 670–684).

problem_text:
If G is d-generator group having no non-trivial finite homomorphic images (in particular, if G is an infinite simple d-generator group) for some integer d ⩾ 2, must G × G be a d-generator group?
John S. Wilson
answer: No, it need not (V. N. Obraztsov, Proc. Roy. Soc. Edinburgh, 123 (1993), 839–855).

problem_text:
Is the minimal condition for abelian normal subgroups inherited by subgroups of finite index? This is true for the minimal condition for (all) abelian subgroups (J. S. Wilson, Math. Z., 114 (1970), 19–21).
S. A. Chechin
answer: No, not always. Let G = [(A×B×C×D)⋊(⟨g⟩×⟨t⟩)]⋊(Y ×⟨x⟩), where A, B, C, D, Y are quasicyclic p-groups, x2 = 1, while g and t are of infinite order. Let A = S∞ n=1⟨an⟩, B = S∞ n=1⟨bn⟩, C = S∞ n=1⟨cn⟩, D = S∞ n=1⟨dn⟩, Y = S∞ n=1⟨yn⟩with ap n+1 = an, bp n+1 = bn, cp n+1 = cn, dp n+1 = dn, yp n+1 = yn. We impose the relations [ABCD, Y ] = [ABC, g] = [ABD, t] = 1; [x, g] = gt−1; [x, an] = anb−1 n ; [x, cn] = cnd−1 n ; [g, dn] = bn; [t, cn] = an; [yn, g] = cn; [yn, t] = dn. Then all abelian normal subgroups of G satisfy the minimal condition for subgroups. The subgroup H = [(A × B × C × D) ⋊(⟨g⟩× ⟨t⟩)]⋊Y does not satisfy the minimal condition for abelian normal subgroups, since the subgroups En = A×B×C×⟨g2n⟩are normal in H and form a strictly decreasing chain. (S. A. Chechin, Abstracts of 15th All-USSR Algebraic Conf., Krasnoyarsk, 1979).

problem_text:
Let f be a local screen of a formation which contains all finite nilpotent groups and let A be a group of automorphisms of a finite group G. Suppose that A acts f-stably on the socle of G/Φ(G). Is it true that A acts f-stably on Φ(G)?
L. A. Shemetkov
answer: No, not always (A. N. Skiba, Siber. Math. J., 34 (1993), 953–958).

problem_text:
A group G of the form G = F ⋋H is said to be a Frobenius group with kernel F and complement H if H ∩Hg = 1 for any g ∈G \ H and F \ {1} = G \ S g∈G Hg. What can be said about the kernel and the complement of a Frobenius group? In particular, which groups can be kernels? complements?
V. P. Shunkov
answer: Every group can be embedded into the kernel of a Frobenius group, and every right-orderable group can be a complement in a Frobenius group (V. V. Bludov, Siberian Math. J., 38, no. 6 (1997), 1054–1056)

problem_text:
Are there infinite finitely generated Frobenius groups?
V. P. Shunkov
answer: Yes, such groups exist (A. I. Sozutov, Siberian Math. J., 35, no. 4 (1994), 795–801).

problem_text:
A group G is said to be (conjugacy, p-conjugacy) biprimitively finite if, for any finite subgroup H, any two elements of prime order (any two conjugate elements of prime order, of prime order p) in NG(H)/H generate a finite subgroup. Do the elements of finite order in a (conjugacy) biprimitively finite group G form a subgroup (the periodic part of G)?
V. P. Shunkov
answer: Not always (A. A. Cherep, Algebra and Logic, 29 (1987), 311–313).

problem_text:
Are
a) the Al¨eshin p-groups and
b) the 2-generator Golod p-groups
conjugacy biprimitively finite groups?
V. P. Shunkov
answer:
a) Not always (A. V. Rozhkov, Math. USSR–Sb., 57 (1987), 437–448).
b) Not always (A. V. Timofeenko, Algebra and Logic, 24 (1985), 129–139).

problem_text:
An infinite group G is called a monster of the first kind if it has elements of
order > 2 and for any such an element a and for any proper subgroup H of G, there
is an element g in G \ H, such that ⟨a, ag⟩= G. Classify the monsters of the first
kind all of whose proper subgroups are finite.
V. P. Shunkov
answer:
The centre of such a group coincides with the set of elements of order ⩽2
(V. P. Shunkov, Algebra and Logic, 7 (1968), no. 1 (1970), 66–69). An infinite group
all of whose proper subgroups are finite is a monster of the first kind if its centre
coincides with the set of elements of order ⩽2 (A. I. Sozutov, Algebra and Logic, 36,
no. 5 (1997), 336–348). There are continuously many such groups (A. Yu. Olshanskii,
Geometry of defining relations in groups, Kluwer, Dordrecht, 1991).

problem_text:
A group G is called a monster of the second kind if it has elements of order
> 2 and if for any such element a and any proper subgroup H of G there exists an
infinite subset Ma,H consisting of conjugates of a by elements of G \ H such that
⟨a, c⟩= G for all c ∈Ma,H. Do mixed monsters (that is, with elements of both finite
and infinite orders) of the second kind exist? Do there exist torsion-free monsters of
the second kind?
V. P. Shunkov
answer:
Yes, such monsters exist, in both cases (A. Yu. Olshanskii, The geometry of defining
relations in groups, Kluwer, Dordrecht, 1991).

problem_text:
The free periodic groups B(m, p) of prime exponent p > 665 are known to
possess many properties similar to those of absolutely free groups (see S. I. Adian,
The Burnside Problem and Identities in Groups, Springer, Berlin, 1979). Is it true
that all normal subgroups of B(m, p) are not free periodic groups?
S. I. Adian
answer:
Yes, it is true for all sufficiently large p (A. Yu. Olshanskii, in: Groups, rings, Lie and
Hopf algebras, Int. Workshop, Canada, 2001, Dordrecht, Kluwer, 2003, 179–187);
this is also proved for all primes p ⩾1003 (V. S. Atabekyan, Fund. Prikl. Mat., 15,
no. 1 (2009), 3–21 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Prove that the free periodic groups B(m, n) of odd exponent n ⩾665 with m ⩾2
generators are non-amenable and that random walks on these groups do not have the
recurrence property.
S. I. Adian
answer: Both assertions are proved (S. I. Adian, Math. USSR–Izv., 21 (1982), 425–434).

problem_text:
Is a finitely generated group with quadratic growth almost abelian?
V. V. Belyaev
answer:
Yes, it is (M. Gromov, Publ. Math. IHES, 53 (1981), 53–73; J. A. Wolf, Diff. Geom-
etry, 2 (1968), 421–446).

problem_text:
7.6. Describe the infinite simple locally finite groups with a Chernikov Sylow 2-sub-
group. In particular, are such groups the Chevalley groups over locally finite fields of
odd characteristic?
V. V. Belyaev, N. F. Sesekin
answer:
No, as every countably infinite locally finite p-group can be embedded as a maximal
p-subgroup of the simple Hall’s universal group U, the unique countable existentially
closed group in the class of all locally finite groups (K. Hickin, Proc. London Math.
Soc. (3), 52, no. 1 (1986), 53–72). But if all Sylow 2-subgroups are Chernikov, then
this is true mod CFSG (O. H. Kegel, Math. Z., 95 (1967), 169–195; V. V. Belyaev, in:
Investigations in Group Theory, Sverdlovsk, UNC AN SSSR, 1984, 39–50 (Russian);
A. V. Borovik, Siberian Math. J., 24, no. 6 (1983), 843–851;
B. Hartley, G. Shute,
Quart. J. Math. Oxford (2), 35 (1984), 49–71; S. Thomas, Arch. Math., 41 (1983),
103–116). When all Sylow 2-subgroups are Chernikov, the same result, without using
CFSG, follows from (M. J. Larsen, R. Pink, J. Amer. Math. Soc., 24 (2011), 1105–
1158 (also known as a preprint of 1998)).

problem_text:
7.7. (Well-known problem). Is the group G =

a, b | a9 = 1, ab = b2a2
finite? This
group contains F(2, 9), the only Fibonacci group for which it is not yet known whether
it is finite or infinite.
R. G. Burns
answer:
No, it is infinite, since F(2, 9) is infinite (M. F. Newman, Arch. Math., 54, no. 3 (1990),
209–212).

problem_text:
7.8. Suppose that H is a normal subgroup of a group G, where H and G are subdirect
products of the same n groups G1, . . . , Gn. Does the nilpotency class of G/H increase
with n?
Yu. M. Gorchakov
answer: Yes, it does (E. I. Khukhro, Sibirsk. Mat. Zh., 23, no. 6 (1982), 178–180 (Russian)).

problem_text:
7.12. Find all groups with a Hall 2′-subgroup.
R. L. Griess
answer: These are found mod CFSG (Z. Arad, M. B. Ward, J. Algebra, 77 (1982), 234–246).

problem_text:
7.16. If H is a proper subgroup of the finite group G, is there always an element of
prime-power order not conjugate to an element of H?
R. L. Griess
answer:
Yes, always (mod CFSG) (B. Fein, W. M. Kantor, M. Schacher, J. Reine Angew.
Math., 328 (1981), 39–57).

problem_text:
7.17. Is the number of maximal subgroups of the finite group G at most |G| −1?
Editors’ remarks: This is proved for G soluble (G. E. Wall, J. Austral.
Math.
Soc., 2 (1961–62), 35–59) and for symmetric groups Sn for sufficiently large n
(M. Liebeck, A. Shalev, J. Combin. Theory, Ser. A, 75 (1996), 341–352); it is also
proved (M. W. Liebeck, L. Pyber, A. Shalev, J. Algebra, 317 (2007), 184–197) that
any finite group G has at most 2C|G|3/2 maximal subgroups, where C is an absolute
constant.
R. Griess
answer:
No, not always (R. Guralnick, F. L¨ubeck, L. Scott, T. Sprowl; see (C. P. Bendel,
B. D. Boe, C. M. Drupieski, D. K. Nakano, B. J. Parshall, C. Pillen, C. B. Wright, in:
Developments and retrospectives in Lie theory. Algebraic methods. Retrospective se-
lected papers based on the presentations at the seminar “Lie groups, Lie algebras and
their representations”, 1991–2014, Springer, Cham, 2014, 51–69). Infinitely many
counterexamples were found in (F. L¨ubeck, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc., 373, no. 4
(2020), 2331–2347).

problem_text:
Suppose that a finite group G is realized as the automorphism group of some torsion-free abelian group. Is it true that for every infinite cardinal m there exist 2m non-isomorphic torsion-free abelian groups of cardinality m whose automorphism groups are isomorphic to G?
S. F. Kozhukhov
answer: Yes, this is true in the Zermelo–Frenkel system with axioms of choice and ‘weak diamond’ (M. Dugas, R. Göbel, Proc. London Math. Soc. (3), 45, no. 2 (1982), 319–336), or if m is smaller than the first measurable cardinal (V. A. Nikiforov, Mat. Zametki, 39, no. 5 (1986), 641–646 (Russian)).

problem_text:
We say that a group is sparse if the variety generated by it has at most countably many subvarieties. Does there exist a finitely generated sparse group that has undecidable word problem?
A. V. Kuznetsov
answer: Yes, such groups do exist; for example, a free group of N3A. By (A. N. Krasil’nikov, Math. USSR–Izv., 37 (1991), 539–553) every subvariety of N3A has a finite basis for its laws; hence there are only countably many of them. It has undecidable word problem by (O. G. Kharlampovich, Sov. Math., 32, no. 11 (1988), 136–140).

problem_text:
Which finite simple groups can be generated by three involutions, two of which commute?
V. D. Mazurov
answer: The answer is known mod CFSG. For the alternating groups and groups of Lie type see (Ya. N. Nuzhin, Algebra and Logic, 36, no. 4 (1997), 245–256). For sporadic groups B. L. Abasheev, A. V. Ershov, N. S. Nevmerzhitskaya, S. Norton, Ya. N. Nuzhin, A. V. Timofeenko have shown that the groups M11, M22, M23, and McL cannot be generated as required, while the others can; see more details in (V. D. Mazurov, Siberian Math. J., 44, no. 1 (2003), 160–164).

problem_text:
Is it true that every residually finite group in which every subgroup of finite index (including the group itself) is defined by a single defining relation is either free or isomorphic to the fundamental group of a compact surface?
O. V. Mel’nikov
answer: No; for example, let Hn = ⟨x, y | y−1xy = xn⟩, n = 2, 3, . . . ; then every subgroup of finite index in Hn is isomorphic to a group Hm for some m (V. A. Churkin, Abstracts of 8th All-USSR Symp. on Group Theory, Kiev, 1982, 139–140 (Russian)).

problem_text:
We say that a profinite group is strictly complete if each of its subgroups of finite index is open. It is known (B. Hartley, Math. Z., 168, no. 1 (1979), 71–76) that finitely generated profinite groups having a finite series with pronilpotent factors are strictly complete. Is a profinite group strictly complete if it is
a) finitely generated?
b) finitely generated and prosoluble?
O. V. Mel’nikov
answer:
a) Yes, it is (N. Nikolov, D. Segal, Ann. Math. (2), 165, no. 1 (2007), 171–273).
b) Yes, it is (D. Segal, Proc. London Math. Soc. (3), 81 (2000), 29–54).

problem_text: Describe the (lattice of) subgroups of a given classical matrix group over a ring which contain the subgroup consisting of all matrices in that group with coefficients in some subring (see Ju. I. Merzljakov, J. Soviet Math., 1 (1973), 571–593). Yu. I. Merzlyakov
answer: If the root system has single edges (Al, Dl, El) and the larger ring is not quasi-algebraic over the smaller one, then it is shown that the lattice in question contains the lattice of subgroups of a free product containing one of the factors (A. V. Stepanov, J. Algebra, 324, no. 7 (2010), 1549–1557), which means that a reasonable description is unfeasible. In almsot all other cases a good description was obtained in (R. A. Schmidt, Zap. Nauchn. Semin. Leningr. Otd. Mat. Inst. Steklova, 94 (1979), 119–130 (Russian); Ya. N. Nuzhin, Algebra Logic, 22 (1983), 378–389; Ya. N. Nuzhin, A. V. Yakushevich, Algebra Logic, 39 (2000), 199–206; A. Stepanov, J. Algebra, 362 (2012), 12–29; Ya. N. Nuzhin, Siberian Math. J., 54, no. 1 (2013), 119–123; A. Stepanov, A. Bak, St. Petersburg Math. J., 28, no. 4 (2017), 47–61).

problem_text:
A group U is called an Fq-group (where q ∈π(U)) if, for each finite subgroup K of U and for any two elements a, b of order q in T = NU(K)/K, there exists c ∈T such that the group ⟨a, bc⟩ is finite. A group U is called an F∗-group if each subgroup H of U is an Fq-group for every q ∈π(H) (V. P. Shunkov, 1977).

a) Is every primary F∗-group satisfying the minimum condition for subgroups almost abelian?

b) Does every F∗-group satisfying the minimum condition for (abelian) subgroups possess the radicable part?

A. N. Ostylovski˘ı
answer: No. A counterexample to both questions is given by an infinite group all of whose subgroups are conjugate and have prime order (A. Yu. Olshanskii, Math. USSR–Izv., 16 (1981), 279–289).

problem_text: Does a normal subgroup H in a finite group G possess a complement in G if each Sylow subgroups of H is a direct factor in some Sylow subgroup of G? V. I. Sergiyenko
answer: Yes, it does, mod CFSG (W. Xiao, J. Pure Appl. Algebra, 87, no. 1 (1993), 97–98).

problem_text:
(Well-known problem). Suppose that, in a finite group G, each two elements of the same order are conjugate. Is then |G| ⩽ 6?

S. A. Syskin
answer: Yes, it is, mod CFSG (P. Fitzpatrick, Proc. Roy. Irish Acad. Sect. A, 85, no. 1 (1985), 53–58); see also (W. Feit, G. Seitz, Illinois J. Math., 33, no. 1 (1988), 103–131) and (R. W. van der Waall, A. Bensa¨ıd, Simon Stevin, 65 (1991), 361–374).

problem_text:
Let p be a prime. The law x · xφ · · · xφp−1 = 1 from the definition of a splitting automorphism (see Archive, 1.10) gives rise to a variety of groups with operators ⟨φ⟩ consisting of all groups that admit a splitting automorphism of order p. Does the analogue of Kostrikin’s theorem hold for this variety, that is, do the locally nilpotent groups in this variety form a subvariety?

E. I. Khukhro
answer: Yes, it does (E. I. Khukhro, Math. USSR–Sb., 58 (1987), 119–126).

problem_text:
7.57. A set of generators of a finitely presented group G that consists of the least possible number d(G) of generators is called a basis for G. Let rM(G) be the least number of relations necessary to define G in the basis M, and r(G) the minimum of rM(G) over all bases M for G. Let G1, G2 be any non-trivial groups.
b) Is it true that rM1∪M2(G1 ∗G2) = rM1(G1) + rM2(G2) for any bases M1, M2 of G1, G2, respectively?
c) Is it true that r(G1 ∗G2) = r(G1) + r(G2)?
V. A. Churkin
answer: b) Not always; c) not always (C. Hog, M. Lusztig, W. Metzler, in: Presentation classes, 3-manifolds and free products (Lecture Notes in Math., 1167), Springer, Berlin, 1985, 154–167).

problem_text:
8.5. Prove that if X is a finite group, F is any field, and M is a non-trivial irreducible FX-module then
(1/|X|) \sum_{x\in X} dim fix(x) \le (1/2) dim M.
M. R. Vaughan-Lee
answer: Proved, even with ... ≤ (1/p) dim M, where p is the least prime divisor of |G| (R. M. Guralnick, A. Mar´oti, Adv. Math., 226, no. 1 (2011), 298–308).

problem_text:
8.6. (M. M. Day). Do the classes of amenable groups and elementary groups coincide? The latter consists of groups that can be obtained from commutative and finite groups by forming subgroups, factor-groups, extensions, and direct limits.
R. I. Grigorchuk
answer: No (R. I. Grigorchuk, Soviet Math. Dokl., 28 (1983), 23–26).

problem_text:
8.7. Does there exist a non-amenable finitely presented group which has no free subgroups of rank 2?
R. I. Grigorchuk
answer: Yes, there does (A. Yu. Olshanskii, M. V. Sapir, Publ. Math. Inst. Hautes ´Etud. Sci., 96 (2002), 43–169).

problem_text:
8.8. (D. V. Anosov).
a) Does there exist a non-cyclic finitely-generated group G containing an element a such that every element of G is conjugate to a power of a?
R. I. Grigorchuk
answer: Yes, there does (V. S. Guba, Math. USSR–Izv., 29 (1986), 233–277).

problem_text:
8.10. Is the group G = ⟨a, b | a^n = 1, ab = b^3 a^3⟩ finite or infinite for n = 7, n = 9, and n = 15? All other cases known, see Archive, 7.7.
D. L. Johnson
answer: Infinite in all three cases. For n = 15 by (D. J. Seal, Proc. Roy. Soc. Edinburgh (A), 92 (1982), 181–192). For n = 9 (and 15) by (M. I. Prishchepov, Commun. Algebra, 23 (1995), 5095–5117). For n = 7, because it contains the Fibonacci group F(3, 7) as an index 7 subgroup, as follows from Theorem 3.0 of (C. P. Chalk, Commun. Algebra 26, no. 5 (1998), 1511–1546) by standard technique for working with Fibonacci groups (G. Williams, Letter of 6 October 2015).

problem_text:
8.12. b) Let D0 denote the class of finite groups of deficiency zero, i. e. having a presentation ⟨X | R⟩ with |X| = |R|. Are the central factors of nilpotent D0-groups 3-generated?
D. L. Johnson, E. F. Robertson
answer: No, not always (G. Havas, E. F. Robertson, Commun. Algebra, 24 (1996), 3483–3487).

problem_text:
Let G be a simple algebraic group over an algebraically closed field of characteristic p and G be the Lie algebra of G. Is the number of orbits of nilpotent elements of G under the adjoint action of G finite? This is known to be true if p is not too small (i. e. if p is not a “bad prime” for G).
R. W. Carter
answer: Yes, it is (D. F. Holt, N. Spaltenstein, J. Austral. Math. Soc. (A), 38 (1985), 330–350).

problem_text:
a) Assume a group G is existentially closed in the class LNp of all locally finite p-groups. Is it true that G is characteristically simple? This is true for G countable in LNp (Berthold Maier, Freiburg); in fact, up to isomorphism, there is only one such countable locally finite p-group.
O. H. Kegel
answer: Not always (S. R. Thomas, Arch. Math., 44 (1985), 98–109).

problem_text:
An g_RN-group is one whose every homomorphic image is an RN-group. Is the class of g_RN-groups closed under taking normal subgroups?
Sh. S. Kemkhadze
answer: No (J. S. Wilson, Arch. Math., 25 (1974), 574–577).

problem_text:
Is every countably infinite abelian group a verbal subgroup of some finitely generated (soluble) relatively free group?
Yu. G. Kleiman
answer: Yes, it is (A. Storozhev, Commun. Algebra, 22, no. 7 (1994), 2677–2701).

problem_text:
What is the cardinality of the set of all varieties covering an abelian (nilpotent? Cross? hereditarily finitely based?) variety of groups? The question is related to 4.46 and 4.73.
Yu. G. Kleiman
answer: There are continually many varieties covering the variety A of abelian groups, as well as the variety A^n of abelian groups of sufficiently large odd exponent n (P. A. Kozhevnikov, On varieties of groups of large odd exponent, Dep. 1612-V00, VINITI, Moscow, 2000 (Russian); S. V. Ivanov, A. M. Storozhev, Contemp. Math., 360 (2004), 55–62).

problem_text:
If G is a (non-abelian) finite group contained in a join A ∨ B of two varieties A, B of groups, must there exist finite groups A ∈ A, B ∈ B such that G is a section of the direct product A × B?
L. G. Kov´acs
answer: Not always (A. Storozhev, Bull. Austral. Math. Soc., 51, no. 2 (1995), 287–290).

problem_text:
We call a variety passable if there exists an unrefinable chain of its subvarieties which is well-ordered by inclusion. For example, every variety generated by its finite groups is passable — this is an easy consequence of (H. Neumann, Varieties of groups, Berlin et al., Springer, 1967, Chapter 5). Do there exist non-passable varieties of groups?
A. V. Kuznetsov
answer: Yes, there do (M. I. Anokhin, Moscow Univ. Math. Bull., 51, no. 1 (1996), 48–49).

problem_text:
Is the variety of groups finitely based if it is generated by a finitely based quasivariety of groups?
A. V. Kuznetsov
answer: No, not always (M. I. Anokhin, Sb. Math., 189, no. 7–8 (1998), 1115–1124).

problem_text:
Describe the finite groups in which every proper subgroup has a complement in some larger subgroup. Among these groups are, for example, PSL2(7) and all Sylow subgroups of symmetric groups.
V. M. Levchuk
answer: These groups are described independently in (V. M. Levchuk, A. G. Likharev, Siberian Math. J., 47, no. 4 (2006), 659–668) and in (V. N. Tyutyanov, Proc. Gomel’ State Univ., 3 (2006), 178–183 (in Russian)).

problem_text:
Suppose G is a finitely generated group such that, for any set π of primes and any subgroup H of G, if G/HGπ is a finite π-group then |G : H| is a finite π-number. Is G nilpotent? This is true for finitely generated soluble groups.
J. C. Lennox
answer: Not always (V. N. Obraztsov, J. Austral. Math. Soc. (A), 61, no. 2 (1996), 267–288).

problem_text:
Let G be a finite group. Is it true that indecomposable projective ZG-modules are finitely generated (and hence locally free)?
P. A. Linnell
answer: Yes, it is; see Remark 2.13 and Corollary 4.2 in (P. Pˇr´ıhoda, Rend. Semin. Mat. Univ. Padova, 123 (2010), 141–167).

problem_text:
Determine the conjugacy classes of maximal subgroups in the sporadic simple groups
a) F′24;
b) F2.
V. D. Mazurov
answer:
a) They are determined mod CFSG (S. A. Linton, R. A. Wilson, Proc. London Math. Soc., 63, no. 1 (1991), 113–164).
b) They are determined mod CFSG (R. A. Wilson, J. Algebra, 211 (1999), 1–14).

problem_text:
(R. Griess). a) Is M11 a section in O′N?
b) The same question for M24 in F2; J1 in F1 and in F2; J2 in F23, F′24, and F2.
V. D. Mazurov
answer:
a) Yes (A. A. Ivanov, S. V. Shpektorov, Abs. 18 All-Union Algebra Conf., Part 1, Kishinev, 1985, 209 (Russian); S. Yoshiara, J. Fac. Sci. Univ. Tokyo (IA), 32 (1985), 105–141).
b) No (R. A. Wilson, Bull. London Math. Soc., 18 (1986), 349–350).

problem_text:
b) Describe the irreducible subgroups of SL6(q).
V. D. Mazurov
answer: They are described mod CFSG (A. S. Kondratiev, Algebra and Logic, 28 (1989), 122–138; P. Kleidman, Low-dimensional finite classical groups and their subgroups, Harlow, Essex, 1989).

problem_text:
Describe the automorphisms of the symplectic group Sp2n over an arbitrary commutative ring. Conjecture: they are all standard.
Yu. I. Merzlyakov
answer: The conjecture was proved (V. M. Petechuk, Algebra and Logic, 22 (1983), 397–405).

problem_text:
Do there exist finitely presented soluble groups in which the maximum condition for normal subgroups fails but all central sections are finitely generated?
Yu. I. Merzlyakov
answer: Yes (Yu. V. Sosnovski˘ı, Math. Notes, 36 (1984), 577–580).

problem_text:
If a finite group G can be written as the product of two soluble subgroups of odd index, then is G soluble?
V. S. Monakhov
answer: Yes, it is (mod CFSG) (L. S. Kazarin, Ukrain. Math. J., 43 (1991), 883–886).

problem_text:
Let G be a p-group acting transitively as a permutation group on a set Ω, let F be a field of characteristic p, and regard FΩ as an FG-module. Then do the descending and ascending Loewy series of FΩ coincide?
P. M. Neumann
answer: Yes, they do (J. L. Alperin, Quart. J. Math. Oxford (2), 39, no. 154 (1988), 129–133).

problem_text:
b) Let n be a sufficiently large odd number. Is it true that every non-cyclic subgroup of B(m, n) has a subgroup isomorphic to B(2, n)?
A. Yu. Olshanskii
answer: Yes, it is true for odd n ⩾ 1003 (V. S. Atabekyan, Izv. Math., 73, no. 5 (2009), 861–892).

problem_text:
Let X be a finite set and f a mapping from the set of subsets of X to the positive integers. Under the requirement that in a group generated by X, every subgroup ⟨Y ⟩, Y ⊆ X, be nilpotent of class ⩽ f(Y ), is it true that the free group Gf relative to this condition is torsion-free?
A. Yu. Olshanskii
answer: Not always (V. V. Bludov, V. F. Kleimenov, E. V. Khlamov, Algebra and Logic, 29 (1990), 95–96).

problem_text:
Suppose that a locally compact group G contains a subgroup that is topologically isomorphic to the additve group of the field of real numbers with natural topology. Is the space of all closed subgroups of G connected in the Chabauty topology?
I. V. Protasov
answer: No, not always: let H be the group of matrices of the form ( (1 z1 r), (0 1 z2), (0 0 1) ), where z1, z2 ∈ Z and r ∈ R. Then H is locally compact in the natural topology and contains a central subgroup topologically isomorphic to R, but L(H) is not connected (Yu. V. Tsybenko, Abstracts of 17th All-USSR Algebraic Conf., Part 1, Minsk, 1983, 213 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Suppose that the space of all closed subgroups of a locally compact group G is σ-compact in the E-topology. Is it true that the set of closed non-compact subgroups of G is at most countable?
I. V. Protasov
answer: Yes, it is (A. G. Piskunov, Ukrain. J. Math., 40 (1988), 679–683).

problem_text:
Construct examples of residually finite groups which would separate Shunkov’s classes of groups with (a, b)-finiteness condition, (weakly) conjugacy biprimitively finite groups and (weakly) biprimitively finite groups (see, in particular, 6.57). Can one derive such examples from Golod’s construction?
A. I. Sozutov
answer: Such examples are constructed (L. Hammoudi, Nil-alg`ebres non-nilpotentes et groupes p´eriodiques infinis (Doctor Thesis), Strasbourg, 1996; A. V. Rozhkov, Finiteness conditions in groups of automorphisms of trees (Doctor of Sci. Thesis), Krasnoyarsk, 1997; Algebra and Logic, 37, no. 3 (1998), 192–203).

problem_text:
Let G = ⟨a, b | r = 1⟩ where r is a cyclically reduced word that is not a proper power of any word in a, b. If G is residually finite, is Gt = ⟨a, b | rt = 1⟩, t > 1, residually finite?
Editors’ comment: An analogous fact was proved for relative one-relator groups (S. J. Pride, Proc. Amer. Math. Soc., 136, no. 2 (2008), 377–386).
C. Y. Tang
answer: Yes, it is (D. T. Wise, The structure of groups with a quasiconvex hierarchy, Annals of Mathematics Studies, 209, Princeton University Press, Princeton, NJ, 2021).

problem_text:
Is every 1-relator group with non-trivial torsion conjugacy separable?
C. Y. Tang
answer: Yes, it is (A. Minasyan, P. Zalesskii, J. Algebra, 382 (2013), 39–45).

problem_text:
Let A, B be polycyclic-by-finite groups. Let G = A ∗H B where H is cyclic. Is G conjugacy separable?
C. Y. Tang
answer: Yes, it is (L. Ribes, D. Segal, P. A. Zalesskii, J. London Math. Soc. (2), 57, no. 3 (1998), 609–628).

problem_text:
Is every countable conjugacy-separable group embeddable in a 2-generator conjugacy-separable group?
C. Y. Tang
answer: Yes, it is (V. A. Roman’kov, Embedding theorems for residually finite groups, Preprint 84-515, Comp. Centre, Novosibirsk, 1984 (Russian)).

problem_text:
We say that a finite group G separates cyclic subgroups if, for any cyclic subgroups A and B of G, there is a g ∈ G such that A ∩ B^g = 1. Is it true that G separates cyclic subgroups if and only if G has no non-trivial cyclic normal subgroups?
J. G. Thompson
answer: Not always. For p1 = 2, p2 = 5, p3 = 11, p4 = 17 let Ri be an elementary abelian group of order p_i^2 and φi a regular automorphism of order 3 of Ri, i = 1, 2, 3, 4. In the direct product R1⟨φ1⟩ × R2⟨φ2⟩ × R3⟨φ3⟩ × R4⟨φ4⟩ let G be the subgroup generated by all the Ri and the elements φ2φ3φ4 and φ1φ3φ−1 4. Then G has no non-trivial cyclic normal subgroups and every (cyclic) subgroup of order 2 · 5 · 11 · 17 intersects any of its conjugates non-trivially. (N. D. Podufalov, Abstracts of the 9th All-Union Group Theory Symp., Moscow, 1984, 113–114 (Russian).)

problem_text:
Give a realistic upper bound for the torsion-free rank of a finitely generated nilpotent group in terms of the ranks of its abelian subgroups. More precisely, for each integer n let f(n) be the largest integer h such that there is a finitely generated nilpotent group of torsion-free rank h with the property that all abelian subgroups have torsion-free rank at most n. It is easy to see that f(n) is bounded above by n(n + 1)/2. Describe the behavior of f(n) for large n. Is f(n) bounded below by a quadratic in n?
John S. Wilson
answer: Yes, it is (M. V. Milenteva, J. Group Theory, 7, no. 3 (2004), 403–408).

problem_text:
Let G be a locally finite group containing a maximal subgroup which is Chernikov. Is G almost soluble?
B. Hartley
answer: Yes, it is (B. Hartley, Algebra and Logic, 37, no. 1 (1998), 101–106).

problem_text:
Let G be a finite p-group admitting an automorphism α of prime order q with |CG(a)| ⩽ n.
 a) If p = q, then does G have a nilpotent subgroup of class at most 2 and index bounded by a function of n?
 b) If p ̸= q, then does G have a nilpotent subgroup of class bounded by a function of q and index bounded by a function of n (and, possibly, q)?
B. Hartley
answer:
a) Not necessarily (E. I. Khukhro, Math. Notes, 38 (1985), 867–870).
 b) Yes, it does (E. I. Khukhro, Math. USSR–Sb., 71, no. 1 (1992), 51–63).

problem_text:
We say that an automorphism φ of the group G is a pseudo-identity if, for all x ∈ G, there exists a finitely generated subgroup Kx of G such that x ∈ Kx and φ|Kx is an automorphism of Kx. Let G be generated by subgroups H, K and let G be locally nilpotent. Let φ : G → G be an endomorphism such that φ|H is pseudo-identity of H and φ|K is an automorphism of K. Does it follow that φ is an automorphism of G? It is known that φ is a pseudo-identity of G if, additionally, φ|K is pseudo-identity of K; it is also known that φ is an automorphism if, additionally, K is normal in G.
P. Hilton
answer: No, not necessarily (A. V. Yagzhev, Math. Notes, 56, no. 5 (1994), 1205–1207).

problem_text:
Find all hereditary local formations F of finite groups satisfying the following condition: every finite minimal non-F-group is biprimary. A finite group is said to be biprimary if its order is divisible by precisely two distinct primes.
L. A. Shemetkov
answer: They are found (V. N. Semenchuk, Problems of Algebra: Proc. of the Gomel’ State Univ., no. 1 (15) (1999), 92–102 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Is G = ⟨ a, b | a^l = b^m = (ab)^n = 1 ⟩ conjugacy separable?
R. B. J. T. Allenby
answer: Yes, it is (B. Fine, G. Rosenberger, Contemp. Math., 109 (1990), 11–18).

problem_text:
Suppose that a countable locally finite group G contains no proper subgroups isomorphic to G itself and suppose that all Sylow subgroups of G are finite. Does G possess a non-trivial finite normal subgroup?
V. V. Belyaev
answer: Yes, it does (S. D. Bell, Locally finite groups with ˇCernikov Sylow subgroups, (Ph. D. Thesis), University of Manchester, 1994).

problem_text:
Does there exist a finitely generated simple group of intermediate growth?
R. I. Grigorchuk
answer: Yes, it does (V. Nekrashevych, Ann. Math., 87, no. 3 (2018), 667–719).

problem_text:
Do there exist finitely generated groups different from Z/2Z which have precisely two conjugacy classes?
V. S. Guba
answer: Yes, there do (D. Osin, Ann. Math., 172, no. 1 (2010), 1–39).

problem_text:
Is there a soluble group with the following properties: torsion-free of finite rank, not finitely generated, and having a faithful irreducible representation over a finite field?
D. I. Zaitsev
answer: Yes, there is (A. V. Tushev, Ukrain. Math. J., 42 (1990), 1233–1238).

problem_text:
The prime graph of a finite group G is the graph with vertex set π(G) and an edge joining p and q if and only if G has an element of order pq. Describe all finite Chevalley groups over a field of characteristic 2 whose prime graph is not connected and describe the connected components.
A. S. Kondratiev
answer: This was done in (A. S. Kondratiev, Math. USSR–Sb., 67 (1990), 235–247).

problem_text:
a) Let G be a locally normal residually finite group. Can G be embedded in a direct product of finite groups when the factor group G/[G, G] is a direct product of cyclic groups?
L. A. Kurdachenko
answer: Not always (L. A. Kurdachenko, Math. Notes, 39 (1986), 273–279).

problem_text:
Let S∗ be the smallest normal Fitting class. Are there Fitting classes which are maximal in S∗ (with respect to inclusion)?
H. Lausch
answer: No, there are no such classes (N. T. Vorob’y¨ev, Dokl. Akad. Nauk Belorus. SSR, 35, no. 6 (1991), 485–487 (Russian)).

problem_text:
b) Let n(X) denote the minimum of the indices of proper subgroups of a group X. A subgroup A of a finite group G is called wide if A is a maximal element by inclusion of the set {X | X is a proper subgroup of G and n(X) = n(G)}. Prove, without using CFSG, that n(F1) = |F1 : 2F2|, where F1 and F2 are the Fischer simple groups and 2F2 is an extension of a group of order 2 by F2.
V. D. Mazurov
answer: This was proved (S. V. Zharov, V. D. Mazurov, in: Matematicheskoye programmirovaniye i prilozheniya, Ekaterinburg, 1995, 96–97 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Let P be a maximal parabolic subgroup of the smallest index in a finite group G of Lie type E6, E7, E8, or 2E6 and let X be a subgroup such that PX = G. Is it true that X = G?
V. D. Mazurov
answer: Yes, it is true (mod CFSG) (C. Hering, M. W. Liebeck, J. Saxl, J. Algebra, 106, no. 2 (1987), 517–527).

problem_text:
Find an algorithm which recognizes, by an equation w(x1, . . . , xn) = 1 in a free group F and by a list of finitely generated subgroups H1, . . . , Hn of F, whether there is a solution of this equation satisfying the condition x1 ∈ H1, . . . , xn ∈ Hn.
G. S. Makanin
answer: Such an algorithm is found in (V. Diekert, C. Guti´errez, C. Hagenah, Inf. Comput., 202, no. 2 (2005), 105–140).

problem_text:
a) Describe the finite groups of 2-local 3-rank 1 which have 3-rank at least 3.
A. A. Makhn¨ev
answer: Described in (A. A. Makhn¨ev, Siber. Math. J., 29 (1988), 951–959).

problem_text:
Let M be a subgroup of a finite group G, A an abelian 2-subgroup of M, and suppose that Ag is not contained in M for some g from G. Determine the structure of G under the hypothesis that ⟨A, Ax⟩ = G whenever the subgroup Ax, x ∈ G, is not contained in M.
A. A. Makhn¨ev
answer: It is described mod CFSG (V. I. Zenkov, Algebra and Logic, 35, no. 3 (1996), 160–163).

problem_text:
A finite set of reductions ui → vi of words on a finite alphabet Σ = Σ−1 is called a group set of reductions if length(ui) > length(vi) or length(ui) = length(vi) and ui > vi in the lexicographical ordering, and every word in Σ can be reduced to the unique reduced form which does not depend on the sequence of reductions. Do there exist group sets of reductions satisfying the condition length(vi) ⩽ 1 for all i, which are different from 1) sets of trivial reductions x−εxε → 1, ε = ±1, 2) multiplication tables xy → z of finite groups, and 3) their finite unions?
Yu. I. Merzlyakov
answer: Yes, there do (J. Avenhaus, K. Madlener, F. Otto, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc., 297 (1986), 427–443).

problem_text: What locally compact groups satisfy the following condition: the product of any two closed subgroups is also a closed subgroup? Abelian groups with this property were described in (Yu. N. Mukhin, Math. Notes, 8 (1970), 755–760). Yu. N. Mukhin
answer: Such groups are described (W. Herfort, K. H. Hofmann, F. G. Russo, Adv. Math., 390 (2021), 107894).

problem_text: (F. Kümmich, H. Scheerer). If H is a closed subgroup of a connected locally-compact group G such that HX = HX for every closed subgroup X of G, then is H normal? Yu. N. Mukhin
answer: Yes, it is (C. Scheiderer, Monatsh. Math., 98 (1984), 75–81).

problem_text: (S. K. Grosser, W. N. Herfort). Does there exist an infinite compact p-group in which the centralizers of all elements are finite? Yu. N. Mukhin
answer: No, it does not exist, in view of the connection of this problem with the Restricted Burnside Problem (S. K. Grosser, W. N. Herfort, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc., 283, no. 1 (1984), 211–224) and because of the positive solution to the latter (E. I. Zel’manov, Math. USSR–Izv., 36 (1991), 41–60; Math. USSR–Sb., 72 (1992), 543–565).

problem_text: a) Let Ω be a countably infinite set. For k ⩾ 2, we define a k-section of Ω to be a partition of Ω into a union of k infinite subsets. Then does there exist a transitive permutation group on Ω that is transitive on k-sections but intransitive on ordered k-sections? P. M. Neumann
answer: Yes, there does. Let U be a non-principal ultrafilter in P(Ω) and let G = {g ∈ Sym(Ω) | Fix(g) ∈ U}. It is not hard to prove that G is transitive on k-sections but not on ordered k-sections for any k in the range 2 ⩾ k ⩾ ℵ0. (P. M. Neumann, Letter of October, 5, 1989.)

problem_text: a) The group G described in the solution of 8.73 (Archive) enables us to construct a projective plane of order 3 in which the lines are the elements of any conjugacy class of subgroups of order 2 · 5 · 7 · 11 together with four lines added in a natural way. In a similar way, we can construct a projective plane of order p^n for any prime p and any positive integer n. Does the resulting projective plane have the Galois property? N. D. Podufalov
answer: Not always. The answer is affirmative for n = 1. But for n > 1 the planes in question may not have the Galois property. For example, if there exists a near-field of p^n elements, then among the planes of order p^n indicated there will definitely be some non-Desarguesian planes. (N. D. Podufalov, Letter of November, 24, 1986.)

problem_text: Let G be a locally compact group of countable weight and L(G) the space of all its closed subgroups equipped with the E-topology. Then is L(G) a k-space? I. V. Protasov
answer: Yes (I. V. Protasov, Dokl. Akad. Nauk Ukr. SSR Ser. A, 10 (1986), 64–66 (Russian)).

problem_text: In a null-dimensional locally compact group, is the set of all compact elements closed? I. V. Protasov
answer: Yes, it is (G. A. Willis, Math. Ann., 300 (1994), 341–363).

problem_text:
Let G be a compact group of weight > ω2. Is it true that the space of all closed subgroups of G with respect to E-topology is non-dyadic?
I. V. Protasov, Yu. V. Tsybenko
answer: Yes, it is true (Yu. V. Tsybenko, Ukrain. Math. J., 38 (1986), 542–545).

problem_text:
Is every 4-Engel group
a) without elements of order 2 and 5 necessarily soluble?
b) satisfying the identity x5 = 1 necessarily locally finite?
c) (R. I. Grigorchuk) satisfying the identity x8 = 1 necessarily locally finite?
Yu. P. Razmyslov
answer:
a) Yes; this follows from the local nilpotency of 4-Engel groups (G. Traustason, Int. J. Algebra Comput., 15 (2005), 309–316; G. Havas, M. R. Vaughan-Lee, Int. J. Algebra Comput. 15 (2005), 649–682) and the affirmative answer for locally nilpotent groups in (A. Abdollahi, G. Traustason, Proc. Amer. Math. Soc., 130 (2002), 2827–2836).
b) Yes, it is (M. R. Vaughan-Lee, Proc. London Math. Soc. (3), 74 (1997), 306–334).
c) Yes; moreover, every 4-Engel 2-group is locally finite (G. Traustason, J. Algebra, 178, no. 2 (1995), 414–429).

problem_text:
If G = HK is a soluble group and H, K are minimax groups, is it true that G is a minimax group?
D. J. S. Robinson
answer: Yes, it is true (J. S. Wilson, J. Pure Appl. Algebra, 53, no. 3 (1988), 297–318; Ya. P. Sysak, Radical modules over groups of finite rank, Inst. of Math. Acad. Sci. Ukrain. SSR, Kiev, 1989 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Find all finite groups with the property that the tensor square of any ordinary irreducible character is multiplicity free.
J. Saxl
answer: Such groups are shown to be soluble (L. S. Kazarin, E. I. Chankov, Sb. Math., 201, no. 5 (2010), 655–668), and abundance of examples shows that a classification of such soluble groups is not feasible.

problem_text:
Can a product of non-local formations of finite groups be local?
A. N. Skiba, L. A. Shemetkov
answer: Yes, it can (V. A. Vedernikov, Math. Notes, 46 (1989), 910–913; N. T. Vorob’ev, in: Proc. 7th Regional Sci. Session Math., Zielona Goru, 1989, 79–86).

problem_text:
(W. Gaschütz). Prove that the formation generated by a finite group has finite lattice of subformations.
A. N. Skiba, L. A. Shemetkov
answer: Counterexamples are constructed (V. P. Burichenko, J. Algebra, 372 (2012), 428–458).

problem_text:
Let F and H be local formations of finite groups and suppose that F is not contained in H. Does F necessarily have at least one minimal local non-H-subformation?
A. N. Skiba, L. A. Shemetkov
answer: No, not necessarily (V. P. Burichenko, Trudy Inst. Math. National Akad. Sci. Belarus’, 21, no. 1 (2013), 15–24 (Russian)).

problem_text:
In any group G, the cosets of all of its normal subgroups together with the empty set form the block lattice C(G) with respect to inclusion, which, for infinite |G|, is subdirectly irreducible and, for finite |G| ⩾ 3, is even simple (D. M. Smirnov, A. V. Reibol’d, Algebra and Logic, 23, no. 6 (1984), 459–470). How large is the class of such lattices? Is every finite lattice embeddable in the lattice C(G) for some finite group G?
D. M. Smirnov
answer: For each g ∈ G the filter {x ∈ C(G) | g ∈ x} is modular (and even arguesian); the variety generated by the block lattices of groups does not contain all finite lattices (D. M. Smirnov, Siberian Math. J., 33, no. 4 (1992), 663–668).

problem_text:
Is a finite group of the form G = ABA soluble if A is an abelian subgroup and B is a cyclic subgroup?
Ya. P. Sysak
answer: Yes, it is soluble (mod CFSG) (D. L. Zagorin, L. S. Kazarin, Dokl. Math., 53, no. 2 (1996), 237–239).

problem_text:
Is it true that, in a group of the form G = AB, every subgroup N of A ∩ B which is subnormal both in A and in B is subnormal in G? The answer is affirmative in the case of finite groups (H. Wielandt).
Ya. P. Sysak
answer: No, not always (C. Casolo, U. Dardano, J. Group Theory, 7 (2004), 507–520).

problem_text:
(A. Tarski). Let F_n be a free group of rank n; is it true that Th(F_2) = Th(F_3)?
A. D. Taimanov
answer: Yes, it is (O. Kharlampovich, A. Myasnikov, J. Algebra, 302, (2006), 451–552; Z. Sela, Geom. Funct. Anal., 16 (2006), 707–730).

problem_text:
Let F be any local formation of finite soluble groups containing all finite nilpotent groups. Prove that HFK = KHF for any two subnormal subgroups H and K of an arbitrary finite group G.
L. A. Shemetkov
answer: This has been proved, even without the hypothesis of solubility of F (S. F. Kamornikov, Dokl. Akad. Nauk BSSR, 33, no. 5 (1989), 396–399 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Find all local formations F of finite groups such that every finite minimal non-F-group is either a Shmidt group (that is, a non-nilpotent finite group all of whose proper subgroups are nilpotent) or a group of prime order.
L. A. Shemetkov
answer: They are found (S. F. Kamornikov, Siberian Math. J., 35, no. 4 (1994), 713–721).

problem_text:
(A. G. Kurosh). Is every group with the minimum condition countable?
V. P. Shunkov
answer: No (V. N. Obraztsov, Math. USSR–Sb., 66 (1989), 541–553).

problem_text:
Are the 2-elements of a group with the minimum condition contained in its locally finite radical?
V. P. Shunkov
answer: Not necessarily (A. Yu. Olshanskii, The geometry of defining relations in groups, Kluwer, Dordrecht, 1991).

problem_text:
Does there exist a simple group with the minimum condition possessing a non-trivial quasi-cyclic subgroup?
V. P. Shunkov
answer: Yes, there does (V. N. Obraztsov, Math. USSR–Sb., 66 (1989), 541–553).

problem_text:
An infinite group, all of whose proper subgroups are finite, is called quasi-finite. Is it true that an element of a quasi-finite group G is central if and only if it is contained in infinitely many subgroups of G?
V. P. Shunkov
answer: No (K. I. Lossov, Dep. no. 5529-V89, VINITI, Moscow, 1988 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Let p be a prime number. Describe the groups of order p^9 of nilpotency class 2 which contain subgroups X and Y such that |X| = |Y| = p^3 and any non-identity elements x ∈ X, y ∈ Y do not commute. An answer to this question would yield a description of the semifields of order p^3.
S. N. Adamov, A. N. Fomin
answer: They are described (V. A. Antonov, Preprint, Chelyabinsk, 1999 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Is it true that in an abelian group every non-discrete group topology can be strengthened up to a non-discrete group topology such that the group becomes a complete topological group?
V. I. Arnautov
answer: This is true for group topologies satisfying the first axiom of countability (E. I. Marin, in: Modules, Algebras, Topologies (Mat. Issledovaniya, 105), Kishinev, 1988, 105–119 (Russian)), but this may not be true in general, see Archive, 12.2.

problem_text:
Is it true that in a countable group G, any non-discrete group topology satisfying the first axiom of countability can be strengthened up to a non-discrete group topology such that G becomes a complete topological group?
V. I. Arnautov
answer: Yes, it is (V. I. Arnautov, E. I. Kabanova, Siberian Math. J., 31 (1990), 1–10).

problem_text:
Let p be a prime number and let L_p denote the set of all quasivarieties each of which is generated by a finite p-group. Is L_p a sublattice of the lattice of all quasivarieties of groups?
A. I. Budkin
answer: No, not always (S. A. Shakhova, Math. Notes, 53, no. 3 (1993), 345–347).

problem_text:
a) Does every group satisfying the minimum condition on subgroups satisfy the weak maximum condition on subgroups?
b) Does every group satisfying the maximum condition on subgroups satisfy the weak minimum condition on subgroups?
D. I. Zaitsev
answer:
a) No, not always (V. N. Obraztsov, Math. USSR–Sb., 66, no. 2 (1990), 541–553).
b) No, not always (V. N. Obraztsov, Siberian Math. J., 32, no. 1 (1991), 79–84).

problem_text:
Is it true that extraction of roots in braid groups is unique up to conjugation?
G. S. Makanin
answer: Yes, it is true (J. Gonzalez-Meneses, Algebr. Geom. Topology, 3 (2003), 1103–1118).

problem_text:
A braid is said to be coloured if its strings represent the identity permutation. Is it true that links obtained by closing coloured braids are equivalent if and only if the original braids are conjugate in the braid group?
G. S. Makanin
answer: No. For non-oriented links: the braid words σ1^2 and σ1^{-2} both represent the Hopf link but are not conjugate in the braid group (easy to see using the Burau representation). For oriented links see Example 4 in (J. Birman, Braids, links, and mapping class groups (Ann. Math. Stud. Princeton, 82), Princeton, NJ, 1975, p. 100). (V. Shpilrain, Letters of May, 28, 1998 and January, 20, 2002).

problem_text:
(Well-known problem). Does there exist an algorithm which decides for a given automorphism of a free group whether this automorphism has a non-trivial fixed point?
G. S. Makanin
answer: Yes, it does (O. Bogopolski, O. Maslakova, Int. J. Algebra Comput., 26, no. 1 (2016), 29–67).

problem_text:
a) Does there exist an algorithm which decides, for given elements a, b and an automorphism φ of a free group, whether the equation axφ = xb is soluble in this group? This question seems to be useful for solving the problem of equivalence of two knots.
G. S. Makanin
answer: a) Yes, it does (O. Bogopolski, A. Martino, O. Maslakova, E. Ventura, Bull. London Math. Soc., 38, no. 5 (2006), 787–794); further generalizations and applications are in (O. Bogopolski, A. Martino, E. Ventura, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc., 362 (2010), 2003–2036).

problem_text:
Is it true that finite strongly regular graphs with λ = 1 have rank 3?
A. A. Makhn¨ev
answer: No, not always (A. Cossidente, T. Penttila, J. London Math. Soc., 72 (2005), 731–741).

problem_text:
Does there exist a non-right-orderable group which is residually finite p-group for a finite set of prime numbers p containing at least two different primes? If a group is residually finite p-group for an infinite set of primes p, then it admits a linear order (A. H. Rhemtulla, Proc. Amer. Math. Soc., 41, no. 1 (1973), 31–33).
N. Ya. Medvedev
answer: Yes, there does (P. A. Linnell, J. Algebra, 248 (2002) 605–607).

problem_text:
For HNN-extensions of the form G = ⟨ t, A | t−1Bt = C, φ ⟩, where A is a finitely generated abelian group and φ : B → C is an isomorphism of two of its subgroups, find
a) a criterion to be residually finite;
b) a criterion to be Hopfian.
Yu. I. Merzlyakov
answer:
a) Such a criterion is found (S. Andreadakis, E. Raptis, D. Varsos, Arch. Math., 50 (1988), 495–501.
b) Such a criterion is found (S. Andreadakis, E. Raptis, D. Varsos, Commun. Algebra, 20 (1992), 1511–1533).

problem_text:
Suppose that G is a finitely generated metabelian group all of whose integral homology groups are finitely generated. Is it true that G is a group of finite rank? The answer is affirmative if G splits over the derived subgroup (J. R. J. Groves, Quart. J. Math., 33, no. 132 (1982), 405–420).
G. A. Noskov
answer: Yes, it is (D. H. Kochloukova, Groups St. Andrews 2001 in Oxford, Vol. II, Cambridge Univ. Press, 2003, 332–343).

problem_text: Let Γ be an almost polycyclic group with no non-trivial finite normal subgroups, and let k be a field. The complete ring of quotients Q(kΓ) is a matrix ring Mn(D) over a skew field. Conjecture: n is the least common multiple of the orders of the finite subgroups of Γ. An equivalent formulation (M. Lorenz) is as follows: ρ(G0(kΓ)) = ρ(G0(kΓ)F), where G0(kΓ) is the Grothendieck group of the category of finitely-generated kΓ-modules, G0(kΓ)F is the subgroup generated by classes of modules induced from finite subgroups of Γ, and ρ is the Goldie rank. There is a stronger conjecture: G0(kΓ) = G0(kΓ)F. G. A. Noskov
answer: The strong conjecture G0(kΓ) = G0(kΓ)F has been proved (J. A. Moody, Bull. Amer. Math. Soc., 17 (1987), 113–116).

problem_text:
Let V be a vector space of finite dimension over a field of prime order. A subset R of GL(V ) ∪{0} is called regular if |R| = |V |, 0, 1 ∈ R and vx ̸= vy for any non-trivial vector v ∈ V and any distinct elements x, y ∈ R. It is obvious that τ, ε, µg transform a regular set into a regular one, where xτ = x−1 for x ̸= 0 and 0τ = 0, xε = 1 − x, xµg = xg−1 and g is a non-zero element of the set being transformed. We say that two regular subsets are equivalent if one can be obtained from the other by a sequence of such transformations.

a) Study the equivalence classes of regular subsets.

b) Is every regular subset equivalent to a subgroup of GL(V ) together with 0?

N. D. Podufalov
answer:
a) They were studied (N. D. Podufalov, Algebra and Logic, 30, no. 1 (1991), 62–69).

b) No. A regular set is closed with respect to multiplication if and only if the corresponding (γ, γ)-transitive plane is defined over a near-field. (N. D. Podufalov, Letter of February, 13, 1989.)

problem_text:
Is the lattice of formations of finite nilpotent groups of class ⩽ 4 distributive?

A. N. Skiba
answer: No. The lattice L of all varieties of nilpotent 2-groups of class ⩽ 4 is non-distributive (Yu. A. Belov, Algebra and Logic, 9, no. 6 (1970), 371-374; R. A. Bryce, Philos. Trans. Roy. Soc. London (A), 266 (1970), 281–355, footnote on p. 335). The mapping V → V ∩ F, where F is the class of all finite groups, is an embedding of L into the lattice of formations. (L. Kov´acs, Letter of May, 12, 1988.) See also (L. A. Shemetkov, A. N. Skiba, Formations of algebraic systems, Nauka, Moscow, 1989 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Is there a doubly transitive permutation group in which the stabilizer of a point is infinite cyclic?

Ya. P. Sysak
answer: No (V. D. Mazurov, Siberian Math. J., 31 (1990), 615–617; Gy. K´arolyi, S. J. Kov´acs, P. P. P´alfy, Aequationes Math., 39, no. 1 (1990), 161–166).

problem_text:
Is a group G non-simple if it contains two non-trivial subgroups A and B such that AB ̸= G and ABg = BgA for any g ∈ G? This is true if G is finite (O. H. Kegel, Arch. Math., 12, no. 2 (1961), 90–93).

A. N. Fomin, V. P. Shunkov
answer: No; for example, for G being any simple linearly ordered group and A and B arbitrary proper convex subgroups of G (V. V. Bludov, Letter of February, 12, 1997).

problem_text: Suppose that a finite p-group G admits an automorphism of order p with exactly pm fixed points. Is it true that G has a subgroup whose index is bounded by a function of p and m and whose nilpotency class is bounded by a function of m only? The results on p-groups of maximal class give an affirmative answer in the case m = 1. E. I. Khukhro
answer: Yes, it is (Yu. Medvedev, J. London Math. Soc. (2), 59, no. 3 (1999), 787–798).

problem_text: Suppose that S is a closed oriented surface of genus g > 1 and G = π1S = G1 ∗A G2, where G1 ̸= A ̸= G2 and the subgroup A is finitely generated (and hence free). Is this decomposition geometrical, that is, do there exist connected surfaces S1, S2, T such that S = S1 ∪S2, S1 ∩S2 = T, Gi = π1Si, A = π1T and embeddings Si ⊂S, T ⊂S induce, in a natural way, embeddings Gi ⊂G, A ⊂G? This is true for A = Z. H. Zieschang
answer: No, not always (O. V. Bogopolski, Geom. Dedicata, 94 (2002), 63–89).

problem_text: Prove that the formation of all finite p-groups does not decompose into a product of two non-trivial subformations. L. A. Shemetkov
answer: This has been proved (A. N. Skiba, L. A. Shemetkov, Dokl. Akad. Nauk BSSR, 33 (1989), 581–582 (Russian)).

problem_text: Suppose that G is a periodic group having an infinite Sylow 2-subgroup S which is either elementary abelian or a Suzuki 2-group, and suppose that the normalizer NG(S) is strongly embedded in G and is a Frobenius group (see 6.55) with locally cyclic complement. Must G be locally finite? V. P. Shunkov
answer: Yes, it must (A. I. Sozutov, Algebra and Logic, 39, no. 5 (2000), 345–353; A. I. Sozutov, N. M. Suchkov, Math. Notes, 68, no. 2 (2000), 237–247).

problem_text: Classify the simple groups that are isomorphic to the multiplicative groups of finite rings, in particular, of the group rings of finite groups over finite fields and over Z/nZ, n ∈ Z. R. Zh. Aleev
answer: Such a classification is obtained in (C. Davis, T. Occhipinti, J. Pure Appl. Algebra, 218, no. 4 (2014), 743–744).

problem_text: Is it true that the lattice of centralizers in a group is modular if it is a sublattice of the lattice of all subgroups? This is true for finite groups. V. A. Antonov
answer: No, not always (V. N. Obraztsov, J. Algebra, 199, no. 1 (1998), 337–343).

problem_text: Let p be an odd prime. Is it true that every finite p-group possesses a set of generators of equal orders? C. Bagi´nski
answer: No, it is not true (E. A. O’Brien, C. M. Scoppola, M. R. Vaughan-Lee, Proc. Amer. Math. Soc., 134, no. 12 (2006), 3457–3464).

problem_text: a) For a finite group X, let χ1(X) denote the totality of the degrees of all irreducible complex characters of X with allowance for their multiplicities. Suppose that χ1(G) = χ1(H) for groups G and H. Clearly, then |G| = |H|. Is it true that H is simple if G is simple? Ya. G. Berkovich
answer: a) Yes, it is (H. P. Tong-Viet, J. Algebra, 357 (2012), 61–68; Monatsh. Math., 166, no. 3–4 (2012), 559–577; Algebr. Represent. Theory, 15, no. 2 (2012), 379–389).

problem_text:
(R. C. Lyndon). b) Is it true that a ̸= 1 in G = ⟨a, x | a5 = 1, ax2 = [a, ax]⟩?
V. V. Bludov
answer: Yes, it is true, since the mapping a →(1 3 5 2 4), x →(1 2 4 3 5) can be extended to a homomorphism of the group G onto the alternating group A5 (D. N. Azarov, in: Algebraicheskije Systemy, Ivanovo, 1991, 4–5 (Russian)).

problem_text:
The well-known Baer–Suzuki theorem states that if every two conjugates of an element a of a finite group G generate a finite p-subgroup, then a is contained in a normal p-subgroup.
a) Does such a theorem hold in the class of periodic groups? The case p = 2 is of particular interest.
b) Does such a theorem hold in the class of binary finite groups?
A. V. Borovik
answer:
a) No, it does not hold for p = 2 (V. D. Mazurov, A. Yu. Olshanskii, A. I. Sozutov, Algebra and Logic, 54, no. 2 (2015), 161–166).
b) Yes, such a theorem does hold for binary finite groups. By the Baer–Suzuki theorem ⟨a1, b⟩is a finite p-group for any element a1 ∈aG = {ag | g ∈G} and for any p-element b ∈G. Now induction on n yields that the product a1 · · · an is a p-element for any a1, . . . , an ∈aG. (A. I. Sozutov, Siberian Math. J., 41, no. 3 (2000), 561–562.)

problem_text:
Suppose that G is a periodic group with an involution i such that ig · i has odd order for any g ∈G. Is it true that the image of i in G/O(G) belongs to the centre of G/O(G)?
A. V. Borovik
answer: No, not always (E. B. Durakov, A. I. Sozutov, Algebra Logic, 52, no. 5 (2013), 422–425).

problem_text:
Suppose we have [a, b] = [c, d] in an absolutely free group, where a, b, [a, b] are basic commutators (in some fixed free generators). If c and d are arbitrary (proper) commutators, does it follow that a = c and b = d?
A. Gaglione, D. Spellman
answer:
No, not always.
For example, if x1, x2, x3 are free generators,
x1 < x2 < x3,
a = [[x2, x1], x3], b = [x2, x1], c = b−1, d = bx3b (V. G. Bardakov, Abstracts of the IIIrd Intern. Conf. on Algebra, Krasnoyarsk, 1993, p. 33 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Let Np denote the formation of all finite p-groups, for a given prime number p. Is it true that, for every subformation F of Np, there exists a variety M such that F = Np ∩M?
A. F. Vasil’yev
answer: No, it is not true. There is a natural one-to-one correspondence between formations of finite p-groups and varieties of pro-p-groups: for every variety V of pro-p-groups the class of all finite groups in V is a formation of p-groups and every formation of p-groups arises in this way. There are continuously many varieties of nilpotent pro-p-groups of class at most 6 (A. N. Zubkov, Siberian Math. J., 29, no. 3 (1988), 491–494) and only countably many varieties of nilpotent groups of class at most 6. (A. N. Krasil’nikov, Letter of July, 17th, 1998.)

problem_text:
A Fitting class F is said to be local if there exists a group function f (for definition see (L. A. Shemetkov, Formations of Finite Groups, Moscow, Nauka, 1978 (Russian)) such that f(p) is a Fitting class for every prime number p and F = Gπ(F) T(T p∈π(F) f(p)NpGp′). Is every hereditary Fitting class of finite groups local?
N. T. Vorob’¨ev
answer: No, not every (L. A. Shemetkov, A. F. Vasil'yev, Abstracts of the Conf. of Mathematicians of Belarus’, Part 1, Grodno, 1992, p. 56 (Russian); S. F. Kamornikov, Math. Notes, 55, no. 6 (1994), 586–588).

problem_text:
a) Does there exist a local product (different from the class of all finite groups and from the class of all finite soluble groups) of Fitting classes each of which is not local and is not a formation? See the definition of the product of Fitting classes in (N. T. Vorob’ev, Math. Notes, 43, No 1–2 (1988), 91–94).
N. T. Vorob’¨ev
answer: Yes, there does (N. T. Vorob’ev, A. N. Skiba, Problems in Algebra, 8, Gomel’, 1995, 55–58 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Does there exist a group which is not isomorphic to outer automorphism group of a metabelian group with trivial center?
R. G¨obel
answer: No, given any group G there is a metabelian group M with trivial center such that Out M ∼= G (R. G¨obel, A. Paras, J. Pure Appl. Algebra, 149, no. 3 (2000) 251–266), and if G is finite or countable then M above can be chosen countable (R. G¨obel, A. Paras, in: Abelian Groups and Modules, Proc. Int. Conf. Dublin, 1998, Birkh¨auser, Basel, 1999, 309–317).

problem_text:
What are the minimum numbers of generators for groups G satisfying S ⩽ G ⩽ Aut S where S is a finite simple non-abelian group?
K. Gruenberg
answer: The number d(G) is found (mod CFSG) for every such a group G. In particular, d(G) = max{2, d(G/S)} and d(G) ⩽ 3 (F. Dalla Volta, A. Lucchini, J. Algebra, 178, no. 1 (1995), 194–223).

problem_text:
f) Let F be a free group and f = ZF(F −1) the augmentation ideal of the integral group ring ZF. For any normal subgroup R of F define the corresponding ideal r = ZF(R−1) = id(r −1 | r ∈ R). One may identify, for instance, F ∩ (1+rf) = R′, where F is naturally imbedded into ZF and 1 + rf = {1 + a | a ∈ rf}. Is the quotient group (F ∩ (1 + r + fn))/R · γn(F) always abelian?
N. D. Gupta
answer: Yes, it is (N. D. Gupta, Yu. V. Kuz’min, J. Pure Appl. Algebra, 78, no. 1 (1992), 165–172).

problem_text:
a) Let G(q) be a simple Chevalley group over a field of order q. Prove that there exists m such that the restriction of every non-one-dimensional complex representation of G(qm) to G(q) contains all irreducible representations of G(q) as composition factors.
A. E. Zalesskii
answer: This is proved in (D. Gluck, J. Algebra, 155, no. 2 (1993), 221–237).

problem_text:
Suppose that H is a finite linear group over C and h is an element of H of prime order p which is not contained in any abelian normal subgroup. Is it true that h has at least (p − 1)/2 different eigenvalues?
A. E. Zalesskii
answer: Yes, it is (G. R. Robinson, J. Algebra, 178, no. 2 (1995), 635–642).

problem_text: Let G = B(m, n) be the free Burnside group of rank m and of odd exponent n ≫ 1. Is it true that all zero divisors in the group ring ZG are trivial? which means that if ab = 0 then a = a1c, b = db1 where a1, c, b1, d ∈ ZG, cd = 0, and the set supp c ∪ supp d is contained in a cyclic subgroup of G. S. V. Ivanov
answer: No, there are nontrivial zero divisors (S. V. Ivanov, R. Mikhailov, Canad. Math. Bull., 57 (2014), 326–334).

problem_text: Can the free Burnside group B(m, n), for any m and n = 2l ≫ 1, be given by defining relations of the form v^n = 1 such that for any natural divisor d of n distinct from n the element v^d is not trivial in B(m, n)? S. V. Ivanov
answer: Yes, it can (S. V. Ivanov, Int. J. Algebra Comput., 4, no. 1–2 (1994), 1–308).

problem_text: Does there exist a torsion-free group having exactly three conjugacy classes and containing a subgroup of index 2? A. V. Izosov
answer: Yes, there does (A. Minasyan, Comment. Math. Helv., 84 (2009), 259–296).

problem_text: For a finite group X, we denote by k(X) the number of its conjugacy classes. Is it true that k(AB) ⩽ k(A)k(B)? L. S. Kazarin
answer: No, it is not true in general: let G = ⟨a, b | a^30 = b^2 = 1, ab = a−1⟩ ∼= D60 be the dihedral group of order 60, and let A = ⟨a^10, ba⟩ ∼= D6 and B = ⟨a^6, b⟩ ∼= D10. Then G = AB, but G has 18 conjugacy classes and A and B only 3 and 4, respectively. From (P. Gallagher, Math. Z., 118 (1970), 175–179) a positive answer follows if A or B is normal. The problem remains open in the case where A and B have coprime orders, see new problem 14.44. (J. Sangroniz, Letter of December, 17, 1998.)

problem_text: Does there exist a finite p-group of nilpotency class greater than 2, with Aut G = AutcG · Inn G, where AutcG is the group of central automorphisms of G? A. Caranti
answer: Yes, there does (I. Malinowska, Rend. Sem. Mat. Padova, 91 (1994), 265–271).

problem_text: Does there exist a 2-Engel finite p-group G of nilpotency class greater than 2 such that Aut G = AutcG·Inn G, where AutcG is the group of central automorphisms of G? A. Caranti
answer: Yes, it does (A. Abdollahi, A. Faghihi, S. A. Linton, E. A. O’Brien, Arch. Math. (Basel), 95, no. 1 (2010), 1–7).

problem_text: Let Ld be the homogeneous component of degree d in a free Lie algebra L of rank 2 over the field of order 2. What is the dimension of the fixed point space in Ld for the automorphism of L which interchanges two elements of a free generating set of L ? L. G. Kov´acs
answer: It is found; R. M. Bryant and R. St¨ohr (Arch. Math., 67, no. 4 (1996), 281–289) confirmed the conjecture from (M. W. Short, Commun. Algebra, 23, no. 8 (1995), 3051–3057).

problem_text: A permutation group on a set Ω is called sharply doubly transitive if for any two pairs (α, β) and (γ, δ) of elements of Ω such that α ≠ β and γ ≠ δ, there is exactly one element of the group taking α to γ and β to δ. Does every sharply doubly transitive group possess a non-trivial abelian normal subgroup? A positive answer is well known for finite groups. V. D. Mazurov
answer: No, not every (E. Rips, Y. Segev, K. Tent, J. Europ. Math. Soc., 19, no. 10 (2017), 2895–2910).

problem_text:
(P. Kleidman). Do the sporadic simple groups of Rudvalis Ru, Mathieu M22, and Higman–Sims HS embed into the simple group E7(5)?
V. D. Mazurov
answer: Yes, they do (P. B. Kleidman, R. A. Wilson, J. Algebra, 157, no. 2 (1993), 316–330).

problem_text:
Is it true that in the group of coloured braids only the identity braid is a conjugate to its inverse? (For definition see Archive, 10.24.)
G. S. Makanin

Is it true that extraction of roots in the group of coloured braids is uniquely determined?
G. S. Makanin
answer: The answers to both 11.54 and 11.55 are affirmative, since the group Kn of coloured braids is embeddable into the group of those automorphisms of the free group Fn that act trivially modulo the derived subgroup of Fn, and this group is residually in the class of torsion-free nilpotent groups, for which the corresponding assertions are true (V. A. Roman’kov, Letter of October, 3, 1990). See also (V. G. Bardakov, Russ. Acad. Sci. Sbornik Math., 76, no. 1 (1993), 123–153).

problem_text:
An upper composition factor of a group G is a composition factor of some finite quotient of G. Is there any restriction on the set of non-abelian upper composition factors of a finitely generated group?
A. Mann, D. Segal
answer: There are no restrictions: any set of non-abelian finite simple groups can be the set of upper composition factors of a 63-generator group; if we allow the group to have also abelian upper composition factors, the number of generators can be reduced to 3 (D. Segal, Proc. London Math. Soc. (3), 82 (2001), 597–613).

problem_text:
Let π(G) denote the set of prime divisors of the order of a finite group G. Are there only finitely many finite simple groups G, different from alternating groups, which have a proper subgroup H such that π(H) = π(G)?
V. S. Monakhov
answer: No, there are infinitely many such groups. If G = S4k(2s) and H ∼= Ω−4k(2s), then π(G) = π(H) (V. I. Zenkov, Letter of March, 10, 1994.)

problem_text:
Can every fully ordered group be embedded in a fully ordered group (continuing the given order) with only 3 classes of conjugate elements?
B. Neumann
answer: No, not every (V. V. Bludov, Algebra and Logic, 44, no. 6 (2005), 370–380).

problem_text:
b) Let F be an infinite field or a skew-field. What conditions on the subring R of F will ensure that PGL(d + 1, R) is flag-transitive on the projective d-space PG(d, F)?
P. M. Neumann, C. E. Praeger
answer: b) Such necessary and sufficient conditions are given in (S. A. Zyubin, Siberian Electron. Math. Rep., 11 (2014), 64–69 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Let G be a non-elementary hyperbolic group and let Gn be the subgroup generated by the nth powers of the elements of G.
a) (M. Gromov). Is it true that G/Gn is infinite for some n = n(G)?
b) Is it true that
∞
T
n=1
Gn = {1}?
A. Yu. Olshanskii
answer: a) Yes, it is; b) Yes, it is (S. V. Ivanov, A. Yu. Olshanskii, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc., 348, N 6 (1996), 2091–2138).

problem_text:
Let us consider the class of groups with n generators and m relators. A sub-
class of this class is called dense if the ratio of the number of presentations of the
form ⟨a1, . . . , an | R1, . . . , Rm⟩(where |Ri| = di) for groups from this subclass to the
number of all such presentations converges to 1 when d1 + · · · + dm tends to infin-
ity. Prove that for every k < m and for any n the subclass of groups all of whose
k-generator subgroups are free is dense.
A. Yu. Olshanskii
answer:
This is proved (G. N. Arzhantseva, A. Yu. Olshanskii, Math. Notes, 59, no. 4 (1996),
350–355).

problem_text:
Let G be a finite group of automorphisms of an infinite field F of character-
istic p. Taking integral powers of the elements of F and the action of G define the
action of the group ring ZG of G on the multiplicative group of F. Is it true that any
subfield of F that contains the images of all elements of F under the action of some
fixed element of ZG \ pZG contains infinitely many G-invariant elements of F?
K. N. Ponomar¨ev
answer: Yes (K. N. Ponomar¨ev, Siber. Math. J., 33 (1992), 1094–1099).

problem_text:
Let R be the normal closure of an element r in a free group F with the natural
length function and suppose that s is an element of minimal length in R. Is it true
that s is conjugate to one of the following elements: r, r−1, [r, f], [r−1, f] for some
f ∈F?
V. N. Remeslennikov
answer: No, not always (J. McCool, Glasgow Math. J., 43, no. 1 (2001), 123–124).

problem_text:
We define the length l(g) of an Engel element g of a group G to be the
smallest number l such that [h, g; l] = 1 for all h ∈G. Here [h, g; 1] = [h, g] and
[h, g; i + 1] = [[h, g; i], g]. Does there exist a polynomial function φ(x, y) such that
l(uv) ⩽φ(l(u), l(v))? Up to now, it is unknown whether a product of Engel elements
is again an Engel element.
V. A. Roman’kov
answer: No, it does not (L. V. Dolbak, Siberian Math. J., 47, no. 1 (2006), 55–57).

problem_text:
Prove that a hereditary formation F of finite soluble groups is local if every
finite soluble non-simple minimal non-F-group is a Shmidt group (that is, a non-nil-
potent finite group all of whose proper subgroups are nilpotent).
V. N. Semenchuk
answer:
This is proved (A. N. Skiba, Dokl.
Akad.
Nauk Belorus.
SSR, 34, no. 11 (1990),
982–985 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Is the variety of all lattices generated by the block lattices (see Archive, 9.62)
of finite groups?
D. M. Smirnov
answer: No, it is not (D. M. Smirnov, Siberian Math. J., 33, no. 4 (1992), 663–668).

problem_text:
Describe all simply reducible groups, that is, groups such that all their char-
acters are real and the tensor product of any two irreducible representations contains
no multiple components. This question is interesting for physicists. Is every finite
simply reducible group soluble?
S. P. Strunkov
answer: Yes, it is (L. S. Kazarin, E. I. Chankov, Sb. Math., 201, no. 5 (2010), 655–668).

problem_text:
Are there only finitely many finite simple groups with a given set of all
different values of irreducible characters on a single element?
S. P. Strunkov
answer:
No; all complex irreducible characters of the groups L2(2m), m ⩾2, take the values
0, ±1 on involutions (V. D. Mazurov).

problem_text:
b) Let r be the number of conjugacy classes of elements in a finite (simple) group G. Is it true that |G| ⩽ exp(r)?
S. P. Strunkov
answer: No, this is not true: the group M22 has order 443520 and contains 12 conjugacy classes (T. Plunkett, Letter of May, 9, 2000).

problem_text:
Does there exist a Golod group (see 9.76) with finite centre?
A. V. Timofeenko
answer: Yes, there is a Golod group with trivial centre (V. A. Sereda, A. I. Sozutov, Algebra and Logic, 45, no. 2 (2006), 134–138).

problem_text:
Is a 2-group satisfying the minimum condition for centralizers necessarily locally finite?
John S. Wilson
answer: Yes, it is (F. O. Wagner, J. Algebra, 217, no. 2 (1999), 448–460).

problem_text:
Let G be a finite group of order p^a · q^b · · · , where p, q, . . . are distinct primes. Introduce distinct variables x_p, x_q, . . . corresponding to p, q, . . . . Define functions f, φ from the lattice of subgroups of G to the polynomial ring Z[x_p, x_q, . . .] as follows:
(1) if H has order p^α · q^β · · · , then f(H) = x_p^α · x_q^β · · · ;
(2) for all H ⩽ G, we have
∑_{K⩽H} φ(K) = f(H).
Then f(G), φ(G) may be called the order and Eulerian polynomials of G. Substituting p^m, q^m, . . . for x_p, x_q, . . . in these polynomials we get the mth power of the order of G and the number of ordered m-tuples of elements that generate G respectively.
It is known that if G is p-solvable, then φ(G) is a product of a polynomial in x_p and a polynomial in the remaining variables. Consequently, if G is solvable, φ(G) is the product of a polynomial in x_p by a polynomial in x_q by . . . . Are the converses of these statements true a) for solvable groups? b) for p-solvable groups?
G. E. Wall
answer: Yes, the converses are true: a) for solvable groups (E. Detomi, A. Lucchini, J. London Math. Soc. (2), 70 (2004), 165–181); b) for p-solvable groups (E. Damian, A. Lucchini, Commun. Algebra, 35 (2007), 3451–3472).

problem_text:
a) Let V be a variety of groups. Its relatively free group of given rank has a presentation F/N, where F is absolutely free of the same rank and N fully invariant in F. The associated Lie ring L(F/N) has a presentation L/J, where L is the free Lie ring of the same rank and J an ideal of L. Is J always fully invariant in L?
G. E. Wall
answer: No, not always; the ideal J is not fully invariant for F/(F^2)^4, that is, for V = B4B2 (D. Groves, J. Algebra, 211, no. 1 (1999), 15–25).

problem_text:
Can every periodic group be embedded in a simple periodic group?
R. Phillips
answer: Yes (A. Yu. Olshanskii, Ukrain. Math. J., 44 (1992), 761–763).

problem_text:
Is every locally finite simple group absolutely simple? A group G is said to be absolutely simple if the only composition series of G is {1, G}. For equivalent formulations see (R. E. Phillips, Rend. Sem. Mat. Univ. Padova, 79 (1988), 213–220).
R. Phillips
answer: No, not every (U. Meierfrankenfeld, in: Proc. Int. Conf. Finite and Locally Finite Groups, Istanbul, 1994, Klüwer, 1995, 189–212).

problem_text:
Is it possible to embed SL(2, Q) in the multiplicative group of some division ring?
B. Hartley
answer: No, it is not (W. Dicks, B. Hartley, Commun. Algebra, 19 (1991), 1919–1943).

problem_text: Let L = L(K(p)) be the associated Lie ring of a free countably generated group K(p) of the Kostrikin variety of locally finite groups of a given prime exponent p. Is it true that all identities of L follow from multilinear identities of L? E. I. Khukhro
answer: No, there are two relations of weight 29 which hold in L(K(7)) (in two generators, of multiweights (14, 15) and (15, 14)) that are not consequences of multilinear relations (E. O’Brien, M. R. Vaughan-Lee, Int. J. Algebra Comput., 12 (2002), 575–592; M. F. Newman, M. R. Vaughan-Lee, Electron. Res. Announc. Amer. Math. Soc., 4, no. 1 (1998), 1–3).

problem_text:
Do there exist a constant h and a function f with the following property: if a finite soluble group G admits an automorphism φ of order 4 such that |CG(φ)| ⩽ m, then G has a normal series 1 ⩽ M ⩽ N ⩽ G such that the index |G : N| does not exceed f(m), the group N/M is nilpotent of class ⩽ 2, and the group M is nilpotent of class ⩽ h?
P. V. Shumyatski˘ı
answer: Yes, there do (N. Yu. Makarenko, E. I. Khukhro, Algebra and Logic, 45 (2006), 326–343).

problem_text:
A group G is said to be a K-group if for every subgroup A ⩽ G there exists a subgroup B ⩽ G such that A ∩ B = 1 and ⟨A, B⟩ = G. Is it true that normal subgroups of K-groups are also K-groups?
M. Emaldi
answer: No, it is not (V. N. Obraztsov, J. Austral. Math. Soc. (Ser. A), 61, no. 2 (1996), 267–288).

problem_text:
(A. A. Bovdi). H. Bass (Topology, 4, no. 4 (1966), 391–400) has constructed explicitly a proper subgroup of finite index in the group of units of the integer group ring of a finite cyclic group. Construct analogous subgroups for finite abelian non-cyclic groups.
R. Zh. Aleev
answer: They are constructed: for p-groups, p ̸= 2, in (K. Hoechsmann, J. Ritter, J. Pure Appl. Algebra, 68, no. 3 (1990), 325–333); for the general case of groups of central units of integral group rings of arbitrary (not necessarily abelian) finite groups in (R. Zh. Aleev, Mat. Tr. Novosibirsk Inst. Math., 3, no. 1 (2000), 3–37 (Russian)).

problem_text:
Is it true that every non-discrete group topology (in an abelian group) can be strengthened up to a maximal complete group topology?
V. I. Arnautov
answer: No, not always, since under the assumption of the Continuum Hypothesis there exist non-complete maximal topologies (V. I. Arnautov, E. G. Zelenyuk, Ukrain. Math. J., 43, no. 1 (1991), 15–20).

problem_text:
Does there exist a countable non-trivial filter in the lattice of quasivarieties of metabelian torsion-free groups?
A. I. Budkin
answer: No, there is no such filter (S. V. Lenyuk, Siberian Math. J., 39, no. 1 (1998), 57–62).

problem_text:
Is it true that every radical hereditary formation of finite groups is a composition one?
A. F. Vasil’ev
answer: No, it is not (S. F. Kamornikov, Math. Notes, 55, no. 6 (1994), 586–588).
